children.text: Eightieth session
Item 137 of the preliminary list*
Proposed programme budget for 2026 – Proposed programme budget for 2026
Part II – Political affairs
Section 3
Political affairs
Special political missions – Estimates in respect of special political missions

table_content.text: The report is the first addendum to the report of the Secretary-General on the proposed programme budget for 2026 under section 3, Political affairs, and contains information on the overall resource requirements of 37 special political missions authorized by the General Assembly and/or the Security Council. Detailed information in respect of each special political mission is contained in five addenda to section 3, Political affairs (A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.2, A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.3, A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.4, A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.5 and A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.6).

The overall proposed resource requirements of special political missions amount to $639,831,500 (net of staff assessment). The requirements include $2,332,000 to provide for the share of special political missions for the financing of the budget of the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe, Uganda, for the period from 1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026.

children.text: The present report contains the overall proposed resource requirements for 37 special political missions for 2026, in connection with the actions taken or expected to be taken by the General Assembly and/or the Security Council on the basis of requests from Member States and/or recommendations of the Secretary-General.

Pursuant to General Assembly resolution 77/267 and established practice, the budget requirements of special political missions are presented in thematic clusters, while the requirements of the United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) and for the liquidation of the United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq (UNAMI) are presented individually in separate reports. In addition to the present report, further details on the resource requirements of the individual missions are presented in the following reports, each of which constitutes an addendum to section 3, Political affairs, of the proposed programme budget for 2026:
(a)	Thematic cluster I: special and personal envoys, advisers and representatives of the Secretary-General (A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.2);
(b)	Thematic cluster II: sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, and other entities and mechanisms (A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.3);
(c)	Thematic cluster III: regional offices, offices in support of political processes and other missions (A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.4);
(d)	UNAMA (A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.5);
(e)	UNAMI (A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.6).

Pursuant to paragraph 7 of General Assembly resolution 77/267, in which the Assembly reaffirmed the established budgetary procedures and practices, the reports on the proposed resource requirements for special political missions comprise two parts: (a) the proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024, submitted for consideration by the General Assembly; and (b) the proposed post and non-post resource requirements, submitted through the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions for consideration by the Assembly.

The overall proposed resource requirements of the 37 special political missions for 2026 amount to    $639,831,500. These resources would be supplemented by projected extrabudgetary resources amounting to $37,700,100, comprising $13,311,400 from voluntary contributions and $24,388,700 from cost-recovery resources.

Any adjustments to the resource requirements emanating from additional mandates or changes in mandates will be presented to the General Assembly as additional reports of the Secretary-General on estimates resulting from such mandates or changes of mandates.

Given the volatility of the security and operating environments of special political missions, should any changes from such environments significantly alter the planning assumptions and costing parameters applied in the current budget, and if such changes cannot be absorbed from existing resources, the consequent changes to either resource or staffing requirements will be brought to the attention of the General Assembly, as appropriate, in accordance with established practices and procedures, and pursuant to the financial regulations and rules of the United Nations.
A.	Status of the extension or renewal of mandates

Of the 37 special political missions for which resource requirements are requested by the Secretary-General for 2026, 15 missions have open-ended mandates, 9 missions have mandates extended into 2026 or later, 1 mission has a mandate ending in 2025, 1 mission has a mandate ending in 2026, and 11 missions have mandates expiring in 2025 that are expected to be renewed or extended into 2026 or later by the General Assembly or the Security Council, as detailed below:
(a)	Special political missions with open-ended mandates:
(i)	Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on Cyprus;
(ii)	Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on the Prevention of Genocide;
(iii)	Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for Western Sahara;
(iv)	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the implementation of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004);
(v)	United Nations Representative to the Geneva International Discussions;
(vi)	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Syria;
(vii)	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Horn of Africa;
(viii)	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Great Lakes Region;
(ix)	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen;
(x)	Office of the Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Sudan;
(xi)	Support to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1718 (2006);
(xii)	United Nations Regional Centre for Preventive Diplomacy for Central Asia;
(xiii)	Office of the Focal Point for Delisting;
(xiv) United Nations support for the Cameroon-Nigeria Mixed Commission;
(xv)	Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon;
(b)	Special political missions with mandates renewed or extended into 2026 or later:
(i)	Panel of Experts on the Sudan;
(ii)	Panel of Experts on Libya;

(iii)	Analytical Support and Sanctions Monitoring Team pursuant to resolutions 1526 (2004) and 2253 (2015) concerning Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) (Da’esh), Al-Qaida and the Taliban and associated individuals and entities;
(iv)	Office of the Ombudsperson established pursuant to Security Council resolution 1904 (2009);
(v)	Panel of Experts pursuant to resolution 2713 (2023);
(vi)	Support to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004) on the non-proliferation of all weapons of mass destruction;
(vii)	United Nations Office for West Africa and the Sahel (UNOWAS);
(viii)	United Nations Regional Office for Central Africa (UNOCA);
(ix)	UNAMA;
(c)	Special political mission with a mandate ending in 2025:
UNAMI;
(d)    Special political mission with a mandate ending in 2026:
United Nations Transitional Assistance Mission in Somalia (UNTMIS);
(e)	Special political missions with mandates expiring in 2025 that are expected to be renewed or extended into 2026 or later:
(i)	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General on Myanmar;
(ii)	Group of Experts on the Democratic Republic of the Congo;
(iii)	Panel of Experts pursuant to resolution 2745 (2024);
(iv)	Panel of Experts on Yemen;
(v)	Panel of Experts on South Sudan;
(vi)	Panel of Experts on Haiti;
(vii)	Counter-Terrorism Committee Executive Directorate;
(viii)	United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL);
(ix)	United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia;
(x)	United Nations Mission to Support the Hudaydah Agreement (UNMHA);
(xi)	United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti (BINUH).
B.	Discontinuing or discontinued missions

The mandate of the United Nations Integrated Transition Assistance Mission in the Sudan (UNITAMS) was terminated effective 3 December 2023 pursuant to Security Council resolution 2715 (2023). UNITAMS completed its drawdown and transition planning in coordination with the United Nations country team during the period from 1 January to 29 February 2024. The administrative liquidation, including the disposal of assets, was carried out from 1 March to 31 December 2024, considering the deteriorating security situation in the Sudan and the challenges posed by an active conflict.

The mandate of the United Nations Investigative Team to Promote Accountability for Crimes Committed by Da’esh/Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (UNITAD) expired on 17 September 2024 pursuant to Security Council resolution 2697 (2023). The administrative liquidation of UNITAD, including the disposal of assets, was carried out from 18 September to 31 December 2024.

The mandate of the mission for the implementation of Security Council resolution 2231 (2015) will expire on 18 October 2025. The last of the restrictive measures (nuclear-related transfers and activities (through the procurement channel)) established in annex B to resolution 2231 (2015) will expire in October 2025. The phased drawdown will be completed by 1 November 2025. No resource requirements were identified beyond 2025.

The mandate of UNAMI will expire on 31 December 2025 pursuant to Security Council resolution 2732 (2024). UNAMI will complete its phased drawdown and the transfer of its mandated activities in accordance with the Secretary-General’s transition and liquidation plan (S/2024/966, annex) by 31 December 2025. The administrative liquidation will be completed by the end of September 2026, under the purview of the Department of Operational Support in New York.

For the mandate of UNTMIS, the Security Council, in its resolution 2753 (2024), expressed its intention, informed by conditions on the ground, to terminate UNTMIS’s mandate at the end of the anticipated two-phased transition by 31 October 2026.
C.	Performance information

In 2024, special political missions continued to play a vital role in the maintenance of international peace and security by contributing to the prevention and resolution of violent conflict and to peacebuilding in some of the world’s most complex contexts. Special political missions undertake a wide spectrum of critical functions, from engaging in preventive diplomacy and supporting the implementation of peace agreements, to assisting Member States in the promotion of human rights, enhancing the meaningful participation of women, and advancing the engagement of youth and other marginalized constituencies in political and peace processes. They also play a key role in strengthening the partnerships between the United Nations and regional and subregional organizations. Across all these areas, special political missions cooperate closely with United Nations development, human rights and humanitarian entities to implement integrated and effective responses.

The various special envoys and advisers appointed by the Secretary-General, presented under thematic cluster I, continued to offer good offices and to facilitate negotiations with a view to brokering peace agreements. Since December 2024, the Secretary-General’s Special Envoy for Syria has been concentrating on establishing stable and inclusive transitional arrangements, aimed at empowering the Syrian people to begin shaping a path toward restoring a unified Syria, one that upholds its sovereignty, independence, and territorial integrity, and can garner broad international support and engagement. The Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen engaged with a range of Yemeni stakeholders, with the aim of de-escalation and maintaining the prospects for an inclusive, multitrack political process to end the conflict amidst significantly escalating situation. The Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Great Lakes Region supported the implementation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework for the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the Region, including through shuttle diplomacy and by providing support to the Regional Oversight Mechanism.

The various sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, Ombudsperson and Focal Point, presented under thematic cluster II, continued to provide substantive support to the Security Council in the implementation of its respective sanctions regimes. The Panel of Experts on the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea ended its work on 30 April 2024,  but the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1718 (2006) continued to oversee the implementation of the sanctions regime concerning the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea. By resolution 2769 (2025), the mandate of the Panel of Experts on Libya was renewed until 15 May 2026. In its resolution 2733 (2024), the Council requested the Secretary-General to report on the implementation of the arms embargo on the high seas off the coast of Libya within 6 months and 11 months of the adoption of the resolution. The Secretary-General submitted his first report on 26 November 2024 (S/2024/858), while the second report was submitted on 25 April 2025 (S/2025/257). By its resolution 2745 (2024), the Security Council changed the name of the Panel of Experts on the Central African Republic to the Panel of Experts pursuant to resolution 2745 (2024) and decided to lift the arms embargo on the Government of Central African Republic and to continue to apply the arms embargo to armed groups and associated individuals operating in the Central African Republic. The Security Council resolution 2744 (2024) replaced the delisting procedure set out in resolution 1730 (2006), and requested the Secretary-General, in consultation with the Informal Working Group of the Security Council on General United Nations Security Council Sanctions Issues, to appoint the Focal Point within three months of the adoption of the resolution, to implement all of the mandates of the original Focal Point established pursuant to resolution 1730 (2006). It also expanded the mandate of the original Focal Point to deal with cases of false or mistaken identity or confusion with individuals included on Committee sanctions lists. Included under thematic cluster III, the United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia continued to support the parties that signed the Final Agreement for Ending the Conflict and Building a Stable and Lasting Peace to implement that agreement. The Mission accompanied the Government in the formulation of the Rapid Response Plan adopted in October 2024 to accelerate the implementation of the Final Agreement, which includes the establishment of pacts between national and local authorities to accelerate the implementation of the Development Programmes with a Territorial Focus and to enhance their transformative potential in conflict-affected regions; as well as actions related to the comprehensive rural reform and security guarantees, among others. The Mission continued to support the transitional justice system to put innovative measures in place to attain peace, reconciliation and the truth and to protect the lives of former combatants and communities.

In Libya, UNSMIL continued efforts to reach an agreement on a constitutional framework that is in accordance with international standards. UNSMIL addressed electoral and governance challenges by facilitating the resolution of the Central Bank of Libya leadership crisis, restoring stability and public confidence and launching a United Nations-facilitated and Libyan-owned multitrack political process. The Mission also continued its engagement with key military and security actors across Libya through a series of dialogues with the 5+5 Joint Military Commission. UNSMIL supported security sector reform and the ceasefire agreement, including facilitating a Code of Conduct session to enhance accountability and professionalism in the armed forces. The Mission provided technical assistance to the Presidential Council to finalize a draft law on national reconciliation which would lay the basis of a comprehensive and victims-centred transitional justice process.

In West Africa and the Sahel, UNOWAS led or supported several initiatives to prevent conflict, defuse electoral- and transition-related tensions, and sustain peace and consolidate peacebuilding efforts in the West Africa and Sahel region. The Mission also used its good offices in support of the conduct of peaceful and inclusive elections in Ghana, Mauritania and Senegal. The Mission worked closely with regional and subregional organizations to strengthen peace and security in the region and to safeguard regional integration. Through the signing of memoranda of understanding with the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and the Mano River Union (MRU), the Mission solidified its existing partnerships and supported the evaluation of the Yaoundé Architecture for maritime safety and security in the Gulf of Guinea. Additionally, the Mission fostered cooperation between Coastal states and Sahelian countries enhancing collaborative efforts to counter the southward spread of terrorism and violent extremism conducive to terrorism.

In Haiti, BINUH continued to encourage Haitian political, civil society and economic actors to unite to address the country’s political and security crises, and engaged with key stakeholders, underscoring the importance of holding an inclusive and participative constitutional reform process as a critical step to the holding of general elections. BINUH continued to mentor and advise senior national police commanders on effectively addressing criminal networks and gangs, especially on anti-gang operations and intelligence gathering. The Mission supported the Haitian National Police in developing a roadmap for the elaboration of a multi-year strategic development plan aimed at strengthening institutional and operational capacities, promoting the rule of law, and enhancing security.

In Afghanistan, UNAMA continued to maintain regular engagement with the de facto authorities, other national stakeholders and the international community on human rights, rule of law, governance and inclusion issues. Given ongoing restrictions on women and girls’ enjoyment of their rights and amid shrinking civic space, UNAMA continued advocacy with the de facto authorities to reverse their restrictions on women, civil society and media, as well as to engage other national and subnational stakeholders. The Mission supported the second and third UN-convened meetings of Special Envoys for Afghanistan in Doha, Qatar, in February and June-July 2024, with the de facto authorities participating in the latter meeting, and Afghan civil society representatives in dedicated sessions at both meetings. UNAMA subsequently supported the establishment of working groups on the private sector and counternarcotics as part of confidence-building measures.
D.	Operational environment and key policy issues related to special political missions
1.	Women, peace and security

In line with the Secretary-General’s commitment to advocate for a minimum of one-third participation for women in mediation and peace processes, special political missions continued to advance the full, equal and meaningful participation of women in peace and political processes and support gender-responsive conflict prevention, peacemaking and peacebuilding efforts. Gender advisers and gender focal points working in special political missions provided critical advice and support to the special representatives and special envoys of the Secretary-General in ensuring that a gender perspective, that addresses multidimensional risks, is incorporated into the political work of the United Nations.

On 24 October 2024, the Secretary-General launched a “Common Pledge for Women’s Full, Equal and Meaningful Participation in Peace Processes” to galvanize mediation actors in overcoming barriers to women’s participation in mediation and peace processes. As of March 2025, the Common Pledge has been adopted by 30 Member States, regional and subregional organizations and mediation actors, which have committed to joining the United Nations in taking concrete steps on women’s full, equal and meaningful participation in all peace processes of which they are a part. Special political missions continued efforts to identify opportunities to push forward women’s participation in mediation and peace processes. In January 2025, the Office of the Personal Envoy for the Sudan conducted a virtual consultation meeting that brought together Sudanese civilians, including women’s groups and youth organizations. These consultations aimed to gather insights, concerns, and recommendations from Sudanese citizens regarding the ongoing crisis, specifically focusing on protection of civilians, humanitarian aid and cessation of hostilities. By fostering dialogue among diverse stakeholders, this initiative contributed to shaping a more inclusive peace process led by the Personal Envoy that genuinely reflects the needs and aspirations of women and affected communities in the Sudan.

In Gabon, ahead of the November 2024 constitutional referendum, UNOCA supported a project on women’s political participation. The project resulted in a roadmap calling for revisions of Gabon’s association laws, the institutionalization of parity over existing quota laws, and the inclusion of vulnerable groups in all public policies. In September 2024, the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General on Myanmar, together with UN-Women, supported a mission of 12 Myanmar women representatives to the Headquarters during the high-level General Debate of the General Assembly. The visit enabled them to share their priorities and concerns and their advocacy with UN bodies and the international community. As a result of the support, the women leaders, who represented various ethnic groups in Myanmar, were able to agree on common advocacy messages.

In Yemen, UNMHA has leveraged quick-impact projects in enhancing its engagement with the parties to the Hudaydah Agreement and focused, among others, on thematic areas on women and income generation. The projects provide an invaluable tool to strengthening local participation in the implementation of the Hudaydah Agreement, inclusivity, and women’s empowerment.
2.	Youth, peace and security

On the 10th anniversary of the adoption of Security Council resolution 2250 (2015), the meaningful participation of young people in peace and security initiatives remains challenging despite   progress in the institutionalization of the youth, peace and security agenda. In April and May 2024, the Security Council held two meetings on the maintenance of international peace and security with a focus on the role of young people. Council members reiterated that violence and conflict continued to disproportionately affect young people, and they highlighted that youth remained agents of positive change and stressed that their needs, aspirations, and voices must be included in decision making.

Special political missions continued to support the meaningful participation of youth in political and peace processes, and to strengthen their engagement with young women and men to harness their potential as agents of peaceful change. In Colombia, the Verification Mission provided training on gender-responsive conflict resolution to youth and security forces, promoting youth-inclusive territorial development. Similarly, UNSMIL organized the Ra’idat programme, which provided training in communication, leadership and teamwork to 30 young women to facilitate their participation in political initiatives. In addition, the Mission launched its new youth strategy, YouEngage, and held 22 workshops with 587 youth from across the country, including 295 females and 292 males.

Special political missions are increasingly supporting youth engagement in environmental peacebuilding initiatives. In Cyprus, the Office of the Special Adviser convened working groups on environmental peacebuilding and on business, innovation, and entrepreneurship. Additionally, the Office supported the 2024 Local Conference of Youth in Nicosia in August 2024 to prepare youth contributions to the twenty-ninth session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. In Iraq, UNAMI fostered collaboration between young people and the government through consultations, resulting in policy papers addressing climate change as well as key social and political issues affecting youth.
3.	Safety and security

Most special political missions continue to operate in complex, highly volatile, and unpredictable security environments. These missions carry out their mandates while managing risks linked to high-intensity military conflicts with significant activity, terrorism, insurgencies, social unrest, among others. Even in countries where the overall security situation appears stable, specific areas where special political missions operate or deploy may still pose serious safety and security threats.

Mission personnel are at considerable risk of becoming collateral targets, while assets and premises remain vulnerable to security threats. For instance, personnel of UNMHA and the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen are present in areas with high kinetic military activity, whereas BINUH operates in an extremely volatile environment marked by rampant armed gang violence, which often overwhelms local security forces. The missions currently in a transition process, UNAMI and UNTMIS, need to carefully consider the safety and security of their personnel and operations throughout these processes.

The factors listed above directly test the ability of special political missions to remain operational and fulfil their mandates. To function effectively in such highly insecure environments, special political missions have adopted robust security measures, refined through ongoing risk management processes. Continuous risk assessment, along with proactive mitigation measures, is essential, including through deploying UN-armed civilian security personnel, guard units contributed by Member States, and, where necessary, engaging armed private security companies as well as a continuous assessment of the footprint.

While host governments bear the primary responsibility for the security of mission personnel, some lack the capacity to provide adequate protection. To address this, the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs and missions’ leadership work closely with the Department of Safety and Security and other entities to refine risk management strategies, ensuring minimal disruption to mandate implementation, including for expert panels supporting Security Council committees during their field visits.
4.	Electoral assistance

During the reporting period, special political missions continued to provide electoral assistance to Member States, where mandated or requested to do so. In her capacity as the focal point mandated by the General Assembly for electoral assistance matters, the Under-Secretary-General for Political and Peacebuilding Affairs receives requests for electoral assistance aimed at supporting and strengthening the existing capacities of national electoral institutions. United Nations technical assistance and capacity-building activities were provided in an integrated manner and, in many cases, alongside preventive diplomacy and other conflict prevention activities, to foster consensus in establishing electoral legal frameworks, focusing on inclusion and non-discrimination, and encouraging broad participation. Special political missions that have electoral mandates continue to ensure that all electoral assistance policies, projects and activities take into consideration the key guiding principles of respect for sovereignty, national ownership and sustainability and promote the political participation of women, youth, people with disabilities and other marginalized groups.

In Somalia, UNTMIS provided technical advice on the electoral legal framework, including the National Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission Bill, the National Electoral Bill, and the Political Associations and Parties Bill to the Ministry of Interior, Federal Affairs and Reconciliation and the Federal Parliament in preparation for the 2026 federal parliamentary elections and 2025 local district and federal member state presidential and parliamentary elections. The mission conducted a series of training in the federal member states on temporary special measures and electoral systems for civil society organizations leaders. UNTMIS started providing technical assistance to the newly established National Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission.

In Libya, UNSMIL provided technical advice and assistance to the High National Elections Commission in preparing for national and local elections. This support, provided in close collaboration with UNDP, included support in the areas of institutional capacity-building, legal advice on electoral framework, the development of national voter registers, public outreach, electoral operations (including electoral procurement and logistics), the participation of women, youth and persons with disabilities, civic and voter education, and the coordination of international electoral assistance.

In Iraq, the Independent High Electoral Commission, with the support of UNAMI, prepared for and organized the sixth Kurdistan Region parliamentary election, held on 20 October 2024. The vote, originally due in 2022, had been postponed multiple times due to political disagreements over the electoral system. UNAMI provided high-level policy advice and technical assistance to the Commission in developing the operational, logistics and security plan, finalizing the electoral regulations and procedures, recruiting and training staff and enhancing systems for the voter registry and election results management. UNAMI also supported the Commission in launching an outreach campaign, using both traditional and social media channels, to educate and motivate voters to exercise their right to vote. Following the elections, UNAMI worked with the Commission to review the processes and harness lessons and recommendations for future elections. UNAMI continued to provide support to the Commission in preparing for the federal legislative elections, including in the areas of overall election management, planning, operations and logistics, information technology, training and procedures, legal frameworks, election security, the political participation of women, public outreach and communications. In line with Security Council resolution 2732 (2024), an electoral needs assessment was deployed to Baghdad and Erbil in September 2024. The assessment focused on the electoral environment and the capacity and needs of the various election stakeholders, with a view to informing UNAMI transition plan and recommending the parameters and modalities of the provision of UN electoral assistance to the Council of Representatives election, expected in November 2025.
E.	Evaluation activities

The Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs continued to support evaluations and audits by oversight entities such as the Office of Internal Oversight Services, while also conducting its own evaluations. When relevant, the key findings and lessons learned from these evaluations are communicated to special political missions to inform their mandate implementation.

The Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs is supporting the biennial assessment by the Office of Internal Oversight Services, initiated in 2024 and expected to be completed in mid-2025, on strengthening the role of evaluation and the application of evaluation findings on programme design, delivery and policy directives. In 2024, the Department also supported the evaluation by the Office of Internal Oversight Services of cluster I country-specific special political missions (special and personal envoys, advisers and representatives of the Secretary-General), which is currently being finalized. Mission-specific evaluation activities are described, as applicable, under the specific missions in the relevant reports.
F.	Lessons learned from the closure of missions and transition planning

In 2024, lessons learned from closed operations were integrated in the closure and transition planning processes of special political missions in Iraq (UNAMI and UNITAD), Somalia (UNSOM/UNTMIS), and the Sudan (UNITAMS).

By its resolution 2732 (2024), the Security Council decided to extend the mandate of UNAMI for a final 19-month period until 31 December 2025 and requested the Secretary-General to prepare, in consultation with the Government of Iraq, a transition and liquidation plan to be completed by 31 December 2024, for UNAMI to start the transfer of its tasks, as well as the orderly and safe drawdown and withdrawal of its personnel and assets, including identification of an end date for liquidation activities in Iraq.

In line with resolution 2732 (2024), the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs led an integrated working group to provide coherent and strategic direction and coordinate with the Mission on the transition planning process. In parallel, UNAMI established an integrated task force enabling the Mission and the United Nations country team to work closely on transition planning. UNAMI undertook a mapping exercise of its activities to plan for their gradual transfer, where applicable, to other United Nations entities and partners, and supported three integrated assessments on key transition issues. In the context of MINUSMA, the Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General, Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator served as the Head of Entity, from 1 January to 19 August 2024, as a key liaison officer with the Transition Government of Mali, the United Nations country team and regional organizations.  Learning from the importance of supporting effective transitions from the closing mission to the resident coordinator, the Resident Coordinator/ Humanitarian Coordinator (Assistant Secretary-General) will become the highest-ranking United Nations representative in Iraq and will assume the functions of the Head of Entity. As Head of the Entity, for the period 1 January to 31 May 2026, he or she will lead the overall governance, coordination, and maintenance of communication with the relevant authorities. Concurrently, the country team took steps to enable the integration of relevant mandated tasks of UNAMI into the forthcoming United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2025-2029) for Iraq, a key step for continued support to sustaining peace priorities.

These efforts informed the United Nations consultations with the Government of Iraq, including UNAMI’s meetings with the Government’s committee on transition issues, throughout the development of the transition and liquidation plan. In a letter to the Security Council on 24 December 2024 (S/2024/966), the Secretary-General presented the transition and liquidation plan for UNAMI, which was prepared in consultation with the Government of Iraq.

The plan detailed three strategic priorities to guide UN efforts in 2025 as it phases out UNAMI by 31 December 2025 and reconfigures the United Nations presence post-UNAMI. The first focused on implementation of UNAMI’s streamlined substantive mandate, concurrently with transition and drawdown, in the areas of electoral assistance, including support to women’s participation; facilitation of progress on outstanding issues between Iraq and Kuwait; facilitation of development and humanitarian tasks and the promotion of accountability and protection of human rights. Secondly, it detailed efforts to preserve gains and sustain continued United Nations support to the Government of Iraq. Finally, the plan mapped out key considerations to ensure the safe and gradual drawdown of UNAMI by 31 December 2025. These individual elements are based on best practices from past transitions to make continue progress during UNAMI’s final year and ensure the United Nations country team is best positioned to continue support the Government and people of Iraq in building a peaceful, democratic and prosperous state.

The Department of Operational Support commenced its engagement with the closure of UNAMI, and experts from the Department visited UNAMI to review initial planning and provide a briefing on support to mission closures. This was followed by a visit from the United Nations Logistics Base team to review property management issues and to conclude a service level agreement governing their support to UNAMI. The regular engagement aimed at ensuring support is maintained throughout the process. This practice enables the Department to both provide advice and support to the closing mission and to ensure familiarity with the issues and plans for liquidation prior to the Department’s assumption of oversight of the Liquidation Entity with effect from 1 January 2026. The engagement with UNAMI will continue throughout the drawdown process and intensify once the mission approaches its cease of mandate and enters the liquidation period. Based on lessons learned from previous closures, the Department will need to provide temporary surge capacity to support the closure process and make preparations for the transfer of residual liquidation issues not completed by 30 September 2026 to Headquarters, United Nations Logistics Base in Brindisi and the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe. The Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance will coordinate the preparation and finalization of financial and budget performance reporting.

Following the adoption of resolution 2753 (2024), the United Nations and the Federal Government of Somalia discussed the UNSOM/UNTMIS transition in a Joint Technical Committee comprising the Federal Government and UN representatives at senior level -- a best practice from past transitions. The Joint Technical Committee met on several occasions to advance the transition planning process and oversee the development of a transition road map. In January 2025, the Committee organized a workshop in Mogadishu bringing stakeholders representing the Federal Government of Somalia, UNTMIS and the United Nations Country Team to discuss modalities for implementing the first phase of the transition process. Based on the discussions of the Joint Technical Committee and the contributions made through the workshop, the United Nations and the Federal Government of Somalia jointly developed a transition road map (see annex in S/2025/194). Furthermore, the United Nations conducted a United Nations Country Team capacity mapping and operational dependencies analysis to inform planning for the post-UNTMIS configuration of the United Nations presence in Somalia, ensuring alignment with Somalia’s National Transformation Plan.

This roadmap details specific actions and the desired end-state for the first phase of the transition, from November 2024 through October 2025, focusing on supporting Somalia’s national priorities . The roadmap articulates key principles to be followed based on lessons from past transitions, as articulated in resolution 2594 (2021). Implementation of the UNSOM/UNTMIS transition will be based on a One-UN approach emphasizing partnerships, capacity building and complementarity, supporting progress towards the 2030 Agenda and Sustainable Development Goals. Joint programming has also been instrumental in bringing various UN actors and resourcing together behind Somalia’s national priorities and will continue to be utilized to foster focus and collaboration in the UN’s support to Somalia. Furthermore, joint UN-FGS resource mobilization opportunities will be explored to jointly engage donors and partners.

The roadmap further notes the transition will be implemented in a human rights and gender-inclusive and gender-responsive manner, ensuring that human rights are promoted and protected through the transition of UNTMIS’ tasks, and that the role of women in Somalia’s peace, security, socio-economic and development discussions is mainstreamed into transitions planning. It will also be informed by risk analysis of impact and consequences of the transition.

Given the unique circumstances surrounding the closure of UNITAMS, which included the rapidly deteriorating security situation in the Sudan and the challenges posed by an active conflict, the process of property disposal within UNITAMS had to be adapted to address the region’s complex operational realities. The mission collaborated extensively with Headquarters to ensure consistency and alignment with United Nations policies and practices on the disposal of assets, including in addressing the remote handover of leased properties, and disposal methods for looted and inaccessible property. The mission also engaged with the Government of the Sudan on key issues such as adherence to the status of mission agreement, security concerns across various locations across the Sudan, and the inability to guarantee environmental cleanup in some operational areas due to the ongoing instability.  These challenges significantly influenced the approach adopted for the disposal of property.

The disposal of United Nations-Owned Equipment (UNOE) in the Sudan was particularly affected by the region's distinct operational constraints. Shipping UNOE to the Logistics Base in Brindisi, Italy, or other missions was hindered by the difficulties in obtaining export clearances, the prohibitive costs associated with shipment for certain items, and the lengthy export procedure which was not commensurate with the mission’s drawdown timeline. In areas where physical access for verification was blocked due to conflict, or where property had been looted, items were written off as losses due to hostile action.

In the case of UNITAD, the asset disposal was facilitated by UNAMI, which played a crucial role in facilitating a smooth drawdown and closure process, including facilities management, logistics and property disposal. UNAMI’s support to close UNITAD was critical given that the Government of Iraq had requested UNITAD’s headquarters in Baghdad be vacated within two weeks following the end of its mandate. Much of UNITAD’s property was transferred and absorbed into UNAMI’s operational pool due to UNITAD’s close operational relationship with UNAMI throughout its mandate. This collaboration supported the transfer of property, records, and evidence, while maintaining accountability, preserving institutional memory and minimizing waste.

G.	Reporting requirements related to special political missions emanating from the General Assembly and from the recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions endorsed by the Assembly
1.	Contribution of extrabudgetary resources to mandate implementation in special political missions

Extrabudgetary resources, in particular voluntary contributions, continue to be used for bolstering backstopping, surge requirements for good offices, crisis situations and other activities related to the mandates of special political missions. Such resources have also been critical for support for inter-mission activities and for visits by desk officers and senior officials to missions.

Voluntary contributions have been important in enabling special political missions to implement targeted projects in pursuit of the implementation of their mandates.  In the Great Lakes region, the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General utilizes extrabudgetary resources to support the implementation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework through various projects under different thematic areas, including the reduction of small arms circulation in the Great Lakes region. The Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen utilizes extrabudgetary resources to support the Special Envoy’s efforts to reach sustainable and inclusive agreements to end the conflict in Yemen. UNOWAS utilizes extrabudgetary resources to support activities to promote peace and stability in West Africa, including to build synergies around climate security and exploit opportunities for dialogue. The United Nations Regional Centre for Preventive Diplomacy in Central Asia utilizes extrabudgetary resources to support the Women Leaders’ Caucus in providing influential leadership on women’s engagement in the countries of the region, as well as activities under the preventive diplomacy academy project, and the Centre’s strategy in support of water, energy and environmental and climate cooperation in the region for the period 2026–2030. United Nations support for the Cameroon-Nigeria Mixed Commission continues to utilize extrabudgetary resources to support land boundary demarcation and to implement socioeconomic projects for the benefit of populations in the vicinity of the demarcation exercise.

In addition, voluntary contributions fund specific mission initiatives. The Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Syria utilized extrabudgetary resources in its role of facilitating the Constitutional Committee through the provision of substantive, logistical, security and support arrangements, including liaison with interlocutors of the Government of the Syrian Arab Republic and the opposition and with civil society, including women’s groups and regional and international stakeholders. The mission in support to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004) on the non-proliferation of all weapons of mass destruction has used funds to facilitate the participation of Member States in events relating to the resolution and country-specific activities. Additionally, the Counter-Terrorism Committee Executive Directorate uses funds to organize meetings in accordance with the programme of work approved by the Committee and support international cooperation in counter-terrorism, particularly a project on forensics and biometrics in Africa.

Voluntary contributions also bolster backstopping capacity at Headquarters, including through funding regular visits to the field, thereby enabling the development of a closer collaboration with the missions. Such visits have facilitated a better understanding and analysis of the context in which missions are operating and how they can be better supported to implement their mandates.

In addition, cost-recovery revenue in some missions, such as UNAMA, enabled those missions to provide shared common services to other agencies, funds and programmes in the same location, to benefit from economies of scale. This is in line with the direction of consolidating support services at the country level and the requirement for integrated support across the United Nations system for the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Cost recovery is governed by rule 105.11 of the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations, in addition to policy guidance issued by the Controller.

Extrabudgetary resources (including both voluntary contributions and cost-recovery revenue) are estimated at $37.7 million for 2026, compared with an estimated $50.7 million in 2025. The projected decrease of $13.0 million is attributable to the phased drawdown and liquidation of UNAMI, the anticipated conclusion or non-extension of some projects or activities in other missions, and to lower contributions for 2026 based on current projections. Extrabudgetary resources have been important in enabling special political missions to implement targeted projects in pursuit of their mandates. However, while missions continue to engage actively in fundraising activities, it remains a challenge to secure funding or pledges for 2026 sufficiently in advance to enable projections to be made with greater certainty.
2.	Regional Service Centre in Entebbe, Uganda

The Regional Service Centre in Entebbe, established in July 2010, currently supports five peacekeeping missions and the United Nations Support Office in Somalia (UNSOS), nine special political missions and the United Nations Office to the African Union, as well as itself. The nine Africa-based special political missions receiving support from the Regional Service Centre in 2026 are: the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Horn of Africa, the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Great Lakes Region, the Panel of Experts pursuant to resolution 2713 (2023), UNOWAS, UNTMIS, United Nations support for the Cameroon-Nigeria Mixed Commission, UNOCA, UNSMIL, and the Office of the Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Sudan.

The 16 clients of the Centre receive the full range of non-location-dependent services, such as invoice processing, financial services for year-end closing, payroll processing, education grant processing, human resources transactional services and travel management and processing, as well as functions such as the primary regional solution for supply chain management and information and communications technology (ICT) services. These 16 clients manage annual budgets amounting to a total of approximately $4.5 billion, making the services of the Centre an essential part of their support operations. The Regional Service Centre will also carry out residual liquidation functions, such as those for UNITAMS, the United Nations Integrated Peacebuilding Office in Guinea-Bissau (UNIOGBIS), the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Burundi, as well as the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA), the mandates of which expired in prior periods, with some administrative support requirements remaining.

The proposed budget for the Regional Service Centre for the 2025/26 period (see A/79/751) is currently under consideration by the General Assembly at the second part of its resumed seventy-nineth session. In that budget, resources in the amount of $46,333,500 are proposed by the Secretary-General for the maintenance of the Centre for the period from 1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026, to be apportioned on a pro rata basis among the budgets of the Centre’s active client peacekeeping operations, as well as special political missions financed under section 3, Political affairs, of the regular budget. Towards this end, an amount of $2,332,000 has been included in the proposed programme budget for 2026, representing the share of special political missions. This provision will be subject to a final adjustment to be made in accordance with the decision to be taken by the Assembly in the context of the budget of the Regional Service Centre for the 2025/26 period, which is expected by the end of June 2025.

In view of the evolving landscape of peacekeeping operations, the Advisory Committee emphasized the need to review the role of the Regional Service Centre within the comprehensive context of the global support architecture, with a view to potentially providing additional services to other entities as well as developing broader cooperation with regional organizations, such as the African Union. (A/78/744/Add.6, para. 12). The recommendation was endorsed by the General Assembly in its resolution 78/294.

To this end, to fully utilize, as needed or upon request, all capabilities of the Regional Service Centre to provide more efficient and effective services, as further detailed in paragraph 68 below, it is the intention of the Secretariat to propose the transfer of the current client missions of the Kuwait Joint Support Office to the Centre. This transition will be completed by the end of the liquidation process of the United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq at the end of September 2026. The transfer of functions to the Regional Service Centre will align with the mandate of the Department of Operational Support in line with General Assembly resolution 72/266 B, and provide the ability, to provide the full suite of transactional services to peace operations on a global basis.

Resources deemed necessary to accommodate the expanded client base of the Regional Service Centre will be presented to the General Assembly in the context of the proposed budget for 2026/27 period for consideration and approval by Member States. In line with current budgetary practice, the financing will continue to be done through proportional cost-sharing among the missions served.
3.	Kuwait Joint Support Office

In its resolution  65/259, the General Assembly noted the intention of the Secretary-General to establish a support office in Kuwait for UNAMA and requested him to explore possibilities for cost-sharing between UNAMA and UNAMI. Following a period of assessment, in October 2012 the Secretary-General informed the Assembly that the Kuwait Office would include a Kuwait Joint Support Office, which would integrate UNAMA and UNAMI functions in the areas of finance and human resources (see A/67/346/Add.4). The Kuwait Joint Support Office was launched in December 2012 as the back office to provide mission support services on a shared basis to UNAMA and UNAMI.

The client base of the Kuwait Joint Support Office has gradually increased over time. It currently supports seven field missions with transactional services related to finance and human resources, while 10 other field missions receive more limited dedicated support only for education grant and payroll processing requirements.

The Kuwait Joint Support Office functions without an independent staffing structure or annual budget. Currently, funding for its staffing costs comes from 7 of its 17 client missions, comprising peacekeeping and special political missions, with UNAMA and UNAMI providing 87 per cent of the Office’s staffing resources. These posts remain on the staffing table of the respective client missions, while operationally they are deployed to the Office and work under the supervision of the chief of the Office.

Since its establishment as an inter-mission cooperation arrangement, the Kuwait Joint Support Office has evolved to become a service provider to peace operations, ensuring cost efficiency, effectiveness in service provision as well as operational continuity in support of peace operations. The Office generates significant cost avoidance, estimated at $4.2 million annually, and approximately $40.7 million since its establishment in 2012.

As a back office for the various clients, due to economies of scale, the Office supported mandated  peace operations outside of Africa thereby filling a critical operational gap in the service provision architecture. In this context, the Kuwait Joint Support Office currently supports 17 missions outside of Africa. It offers a service model tailored to the needs of its client missions and enjoys high client satisfaction rates for its services.

Over its lifetime, the Kuwait Joint Support Office has successfully demonstrated the efficiency, effectiveness, emergency response capacities, and operational resilience of a shared services model. It has generated a critical knowledge base and talent pool that will be valuable as the Secretariat continues to refine its global operational support architecture.

In view of the drawdown and liquidation of UNAMI, the Department of Operational Support conducted a review of the Kuwait Joint Support Office that focused on ensuring that the 16 peace operations (excluding UNAMI) that are currently supported by the Kuwait Joint Support Office could continue to receive shared services with efficiency, interoperability, responsiveness, and operational continuity with the termination of the mandate for UNAMI at the end of 2025.

In line with the recommendation of the Advisory Committee, endorsed by the General Assembly in its resolution 78/294, to review the role of the Regional Service Centre within the comprehensive context of the global support architecture, the Secretariat intends to transfer the 16 client missions currently supported by the Kuwait Joint Support Office to the Regional Service Centre.

Upon review by the ACABQ and approval by Member States, the transfer would establish a more integrated support model, consolidating the provision of transactional services for peacekeeping and special political missions within a single service provider, in line with the global mandate of DOS and RSCE. If approved, the formal transition would become effective from 1 July 2026, with a transition period up to 30 September 2026.

The transition of the Kuwait Joint Support Office’s 16 client missions to a new service provider is a complex, multi-faceted process requiring extensive planning, coordination, and execution involving multiple stakeholders. To enable a seamless and fully supported transition, it is essential to maintain the full scope of Kuwait Joint Support Office’s operations to ensure sufficient capacity to prepare for and implement the transition, aligned with the projected timeline for the complete liquidation of UNAMI.

Accordingly, funding for the 64 posts currently contributed by UNAMI, UNAMA and BINUH, along with operational costs jointly contributed by 10 special political missions, are proposed to be maintained until 30 September 2026 in the proposed budget for 2026. The proposed budgets for these three entities for 2026 reflect the proposed abolishment of the 64 posts as of 1 October 2026.

As mentioned in para 60 above, the related resources for the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe will be proposed in the proposed budget for the centre for 2026/27. Adjustments will also be proposed to the five peacekeeping entities that currently provide staff resources to the Kuwait Joint Support Office, to reflect the discontinuation of such resources in the proposed budgets for the respective entities for 2026/27.
4.	Promoting national capacities

Encouraging the use of national capacities has been a core area of focus in human resources management in special political missions. In line with the request of the General Assembly in its resolutions 61/276 and 66/264 for greater utilization of national staff, and through the guidance provided in the Workforce Planning Nationalization Guide (December 2021), special political missions reviewed their staffing requirements prior to the budget submission to determine the feasibility of nationalization, commensurate with the requirements of the missions and their respective mandates.

According to the above Guidance, when identifying opportunities for nationalization, special political missions use the following criteria: (a) identification of vacant international post and positions, including United Nations Volunteer positions, which could be considered for conversion to national posts or positions; (b) in the case of any changes in mandate, determine whether the function remained necessary to meet the objectives of the mission and maintain the international character of the operation; (c) assess whether there might be a perception of conflict of interest for the function; (d) determine whether the function required movement across international borders or lines of conflict regularly; (e) determine whether the function had security-related requirements that prohibited specific categories of staff; and (f) determine the availability of talent in the local labour market, including the required knowledge and skills. The rate of nationalization hence is dynamic and can be affected if there is a lack of qualifications in the local labour market which tends to occur in conflict-affected areas where the local educational system and pool of qualified candidates may have been disrupted.

The conditions and criteria for nationalization outlined above are furthered assessed against each mission’s operational context. Missions were encouraged to ensure that national staff are empowered and skilled to carry out the implementation of the mandate while ensuring that the international character of the mission is maintained.

In recent years, special political missions have made steady progress in the nationalization of posts. For 2026, it is proposed that 1 post be nationalized in the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen, 2 additional national posts be established in the Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon, and 9 national United Nations Volunteers be converted from extrabudgetary resources in UNAMA, as indicated in table 1 below.

children.text: 5.	Gender parity and geographical representation

The Organization remains committed to achieving gender parity, guided by the principles of merit and fairness in all selection processes. Efforts are ongoing to advance gender parity, with a renewed focus on strengthening recruitment, particularly through proactive outreach, amongst other efforts. While financial constraints have led to temporary freezes on recruitment, the Organization remains committed to continuing existing efforts and expanding targeted engagement, especially for field-based roles in special political missions. Outreach strategies are being refined to maintain momentum and ensure a steady pipeline of diverse talent.

Improving living and working conditions in field duty stations continues to be a critical priority for the recruitment and retention of women. The Organization remains committed to applying the six thematic areas of the Field-specific Enabling Environment Guidelines to further strengthen recruitment and retention in these settings. Addressing organizational culture is crucial to achieving lasting progress. The results of the 2024 staff engagement survey present an opportunity to deliberately identify and address persistent gaps. These insights will guide continued efforts to build respectful and supportive workplaces across all duty stations. Also critical are ongoing efforts to address the mental health and well-being of all staff, with particular attention to those serving in hardship duty stations who often face heightened stressors and unique challenges.

Missions also seek to integrate a gender perspective in their operational activities, deliverables and results. To diversify the geographical and gender composition of sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, the Department participated, in October 2024, alongside other UN Secretariat entities, in the ImpactPool virtual career fair for Women in Senior Roles, hosted by a career web platform specializing in humanitarian and international jobs. A total of 2,343 women registered for the career fair, of whom 459 (from countries across all regional groups) visited the joint UN Secretariat's virtual booth containing presentations, fact sheets, videos and information on job openings for sanctions experts. In addition, in May and June 2024, the Department briefed representatives of the Group of African States, the Group of Arab States, the Group of Eastern European States, and the Group of Latin America and the Caribbean States on the recruitment process of members of sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels.

In its engagement with the de facto authorities and political stakeholders, UNAMA promotes gender mainstreaming into programmes and structures to strengthen the representation of women. The Mission supports the implementation of Security Council resolutions 1325 (2000) and 2493 (2019), in particular with regard to gender equality, the empowerment of women and girls and their human rights. In view of the low percentage of female national staff within the Mission, UNAMA is continuously undertaking efforts to address challenges that prevent the attainment of gender parity through capacity-building of women. The national United Nations Volunteers play a critical role in the mission's activities both in substantive and mission-support sections, and are essential for achieving and maintaining UNAMA's mandate, including by integrating Afghan women's perspectives in all areas of work and enhancing the Mission’s capacity to reach local communities and the most vulnerable groups. In line with the efforts to continue to improve the gender balance in the Mission’s staffing, and taking into account the prospects of shrinking extrabudgetary resources, it is proposed that the existing nine female national United Nations Volunteer positions currently funded from extrabudgetary resources be converted to regular budget funding in 2026, to continue to support programmes of work of components across the Mission. The conversion provides some element of assured continuity in this flagship initiative which supports the advancement of women's involvement in society and support UNAMA's gender parity efforts to employ and empower young professional Afghan women who would otherwise be struggling to find professional purpose in their lives after graduation.

The Secretariat remains committed to accelerating progress towards equitable geographical distribution in posts subject to geographical distribution, and to promoting as wide a geographical basis as possible in the recruitment of staff for non-geographical posts, including those in special political missions and peacekeeping operations. Achieving equitable geographical distribution and greater geographical representation requires sustained and deliberate action, particularly in light of systemic challenges and legacy recruitment patterns. As highlighted in the Secretary-General’s report on ways forward in the implementation of human resources management reforms for the period 2023–2026 (A/77/590), financial constraints and structural issues in the staff selection system continue to hinder faster progress towards the equitable geographical distribution goal.

In response, the Secretariat is reforming its staff selection framework. The implementation of the Staff Selection 2.0 initiative is well underway, aiming to foster a fair, efficient, effective, and agile recruitment system. This initiative is expected to significantly enhance the Secretariat’s ability to attract and select staff from a wide geographical base.  Concurrently, the Secretariat has recalibrated its talent attraction approaches, including through the development of purposeful partnerships with Member States. These efforts are aimed at positioning the United Nations as an employer of choice and at cultivating diverse talent pipelines to meet both current and future workforce needs. This forward-looking approach is designed to ensure a continuous flow of qualified candidates and to strengthen workforce readiness. While substantive change will require time, incremental progress is anticipated in the short to medium term. The Secretariat underscores the importance of adequate resources to sustain and scale talent outreach initiatives. Additional investments would enhance the Secretariat’s capacity to engage meaningfully with Member States and to implement outreach activities in support of equitable geographical distribution.

To deliver the mandates of special political missions in changing operational environments, including by leveraging data, technology and innovation, a set of workforce capabilities will be reinforced over the coming years. For example, building data expertise, innovation capacity, digital dexterity and strategic foresight, and leveraging behavioural science, are priorities, along with strengthening capabilities in strategic communications. New generic job profiles covering these capabilities have been developed or are under development. Proposals for reclassification and reassignment of existing functions in missions using these new profiles, especially when leveraging opportunities from upcoming retirements to create more junior-level posts to rejuvenate the workforce, are vital elements in advancing a workforce transformation.

Efforts continue to ensure that human resources policies are responsive to the needs of entities with a field presence. Specifically, the Office of Human Resources develops and revises administrative issuances, streamlined policies and procedures to respond to the needs of field entities and provides authoritative policy interpretation and advice on all human resources policies applicable to field entities, including in emergency and crisis situations, as well as during downsizing and reduction-of-staff exercises. The Office remains actively engaged in the work of the Human Resources Network Standing Committee on Field Duty Stations and the International Civil Service Commission’s tripartite Working Group for the Review of Conditions of Life and Work in Field Duty Stations, which monitor matters related to the conditions of service of staff in the field, including rest and recuperation, danger pay, hardship classification and non-family designation of duty stations. As part of the Office’s participation in discussions of the International Civil Service Commission, ongoing reviews are carried out for key field entitlements, including hardship allowance, non-family service allowance, mobility incentive, relocation package, danger pay and security evacuation allowance, as well as the methodology for setting post adjustment in field duty stations. The Office is actively engaged in the comprehensive review of the United Nations common system compensation package being conducted by the International Civil Service Commission pursuant to General Assembly resolution 77/256 B, which includes a full review of the compensation package for staff in field locations. The Office also conducts periodic salary surveys to establish and update salary scales for staff in locally recruited categories in field duty stations.
6.	Strengthening coherence and collaboration between pillars in special political missions

Depending on the context of the country and mission, the Deputy Special Representatives of the Secretary-General may have triple functions to perform, also serving as resident coordinators and humanitarian coordinators. The staffing complements of six special political missions, namely UNTMIS, the Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon, UNSMIL, BINUH, UNAMA and UNAMI, include Deputy Special Representatives of the Secretary-General, or Deputy Special Coordinators, who have the triple functions and serve also as resident coordinators and humanitarian coordinators in complex, multidimensional contexts. These deputies constitute the link between the political work of the special political mission and the United Nations entities implementing development and humanitarian activities in coordination with the mission. As Resident Coordinator, the incumbent is responsible for coordinating operations and activities relating to the United Nations country team and United Nations development activities, for ensuring that the activities of the United Nations country team are aligned with national priorities, as captured in United Nations cooperation frameworks, for providing oversight and transparency on joint activities of the United Nations country team and for mobilizing partnerships and financing in support of country efforts towards the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. The office of the resident coordinator supports those functions. As Humanitarian Coordinator, the incumbent is responsible for coordinating humanitarian plans and operations and for maintaining links with Governments and other parties, donors and the broader humanitarian community. The salaries and common staff costs related to the posts of Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General, Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator are budgeted at 50 per cent of the total cost in the 2025 budgets of the respective special political missions, pursuant to General Assembly resolutions 59/296 and 72/279, with the other 50 per cent funded through the Development Coordination Office. In line with Security Council resolution 2594 (2021), the Secretariat continues to strengthen coherence and collaboration between the respective pillars in mission settings.

Appropriately sized and dedicated capacity in the mission structure is required to support the Deputy Special Representative, Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator in carrying out their cross-pillar function within the respective mission and to provide sufficient support to their role in coordinating the work of the various units reporting to them. Where needed, the Secretariat will apply the two criteria of its policy in ascertaining the level of support capacity for the Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General, Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator: (a) the number of units reporting to him or her; and (b) the number of substantive mandate points assigned to the office. (see A/79/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.1, paragraph 79).
7.	Mine action activities

Pursuant to recommendations from the Board of Auditors (see A/75/5 (Vol. II) and A/76/5 (Vol. II)), the Secretariat initiated the phased review and redesign of its mine action programmes in peacekeeping missions and special political missions to improve effectiveness, governance and transparency, and cost efficiency, by reviewing and redesigning the delivery of mine action mandates in UNAMA and UNSMIL. The redesign shifted delivery from implementation in partnership with the United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) to direct delivery by the Secretariat. This shift improves governance by providing a direct reporting line from the mine action personnel to the Chief of the Mine Action Programme and empowering the Secretariat to fulfil its responsibilities to undertake programme design, operational planning, implementation, reporting and representation.

The first phase of the review concluded with the transition of the mine action programmes from delivery in partnership to UNOPS to Secretariat direct delivery in United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon and the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei as from 1 July 2024, and in UNAMA and UNSMIL from 1 January 2025. Given that this process has been completed for special political missions, no more proposals are made in the proposed budget for 2026. While UNOPS will no longer be involved in delivery of mine action programmes in special political missions, the Secretariat will continue to perform the core functions of programme design, operational planning, contract requisitioning, implementation, oversight, reporting and representation for mine action programmes.
8.	Backstopping support at Headquarters

Special political missions rely on Headquarters for backstopping support for a wide range of functions. The Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs is leading and providing substantive backstopping to 34 of the 37 continuing special political missions by ensuring regular and effective communication between the missions and United Nations entities in New York and regular liaison with Member States through their permanent missions to the United Nations and preparing a wide range of substantive material, including briefing material for the Security Council and regular reports of the Secretary-General, among other functions. Administrative support is being provided by the joint Executive Office of the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs and the Department of Peace Operations to 15 of those missions.

Special political missions also benefit from operational support and advisory services in the areas of human resources and supply chain management provided by the Department of Operational Support; budgetary and financial services, asset and property management policy support and assistance with accountability systems provided by Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance; and information technology support delivered by the Office of Information and Communications Technology. Special political missions also rely on support from Headquarters in thematic and operational areas such as constitution-making, electoral assistance, mediation, best practices, military and police planning/force generation, rule of law and security institutions.

As outlined in detail in the Secretary-General’s report on the review of arrangements for funding and backstopping special political missions (A/66/340), which remained pending before the General Assembly, there is no dedicated mechanism to ensure relevant capacities for backstopping special political missions at Headquarters, in contrast to peacekeeping operations, which can draw on the support account for peacekeeping operations.

In 2025, a total of 45 posts (1 D-1, 8 P-5, 19 P-4, 7 P-3, 1 P-2 and 9 General Service (Other level)) are being funded from special political missions. In 2026, a total of 40 such posts (1 D-1, 8 P-5, 17 P-4, 5 P-3 and 9 General Service (Other level)) are proposed, reflecting the abolishment of 4 posts as of 1 January 2026 due to the end of mandate of UNAMI and the proposed abolishment of 1 post for UNMHA. In addition, due to the expected end of mandate of UNTMIS, it is proposed that 3 posts are abolished as of 31 October 2026.

While the resources included in the budgets of special political missions for backstopping support are fundamental for the Secretariat to provide support to special political missions, the regular budget and extrabudgetary resources of the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs are often also required to ensure adequate support. Similarly, the regular budget and extrabudgetary resources of the Office for Disarmament Affairs are used to provide administrative support to the mission in support of the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004) on the non-proliferation of all weapons of mass destruction.
9.	Ratios for vehicles and information technology equipment

In its resolution 79/258 A, the General Assembly requested the Secretary-General to update the vehicle holding ratio and related guidance, as well as the computing device allocation ratio, to enable the missions to improve the transparency and accuracy of the relevant budgets. The standard ratio for light passenger vehicle is promulgated to provide guidance in the determination of the ceiling holdings for operational purposes to support mission in ensuring effective and efficient fleet management considering the relevance to operations in any given Secretariat entity. As  ratios are not mandatory, the actual holdings are determined by missions based on local conditions and their unique operational requirements, which for vehicles should be prioritized on the basis of supporting mileage, frequency of use and usage patterns. The missions continue to monitor excess holdings of vehicles and expect to dispose of vehicles when they meet the criteria in terms of life expectancy or write-off or to recommend inter-mission transfers where feasible and cost-efficient.

Within the context of vehicle fleet transformation into a more cost efficient and environmentally friendly UN fleet, the Secretariat remains responsible for establishing sourcing solutions for cost-efficient vehicles available under Headquarters global systems contracts established through competitive bidding exercises.

In the above context, the holdings of vehicles and information technology equipment are proposed on the basis of the anticipated personnel incumbency levels planned for 2026, as opposed to the full authorized level of personnel.
