Similarly, the guidelines issued by the Office of Communications and Technology reinforced the “one computing device per user” policy as a best-practice reference to improve budget discipline, cost-effectiveness, and alignment with Secretariat-wide ICT governance. Individual missions may deviate from the guidelines based on operational requirements. The total proposed vehicle holdings for special political missions are 11.0 per cent above the standard allocation based on the Standard Cost and Ratio Manual. Provisions of new or replacement vehicles to missions take into consideration the operational circumstances, including the terrain and infrastructure in the area of operations, security considerations and the supply and availability of spare parts. Explanations for vehicle holdings that are higher than the standard allocation in specific missions are as follows:

(a)	The vehicle holdings for the United Nations Representative to the Geneva International Discussions are 33.3 per cent, or one vehicle, higher than the standard allocation, and reflect the operational needs both in Tbilisi and Zugdidi, Georgia;
(b)	The vehicle holdings for UNOWAS are 6.7 per cent, or one vehicle, higher than the standard allocation, and reflect the operational needs for a vehicle in Abuja to support the SRSG visits;

(c)	The vehicle holdings for United Nations support for the Cameroon-Nigeria Mixed Commission are higher than the standard allocation by 60.0 per cent, which reflects the need for dedicated transportation to support the movement of the joint technical teams and their security personnel along with all their logistics equipment while in the field. The presence of these vehicles allows for flexibility and the ability to move freely within the areas of operations, many of which are isolated and hard to reach and have limited infrastructure and unsafe conditions;

(d)		The vehicle holdings for the Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon are higher than the standard allocation by 22.2 per cent, or two vehicles, and reflect the operational need to support official meetings and engagement across Lebanon;
(e)		The vehicle holdings for UNOCA are higher than the standard allocation by10.0 per cent, or one vehicle, and reflect operational needs.;

(f)	The vehicle holdings for UNSMIL are 10.9 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to: (i) an operational requirement for a pool of vehicles to support the United Nations Guard Unit; and (ii) reserves to support movements in Tunis and Benghazi. UNSMIL operates in two countries (Libya and Tunisia) and in five official locations (Tripoli, Benghazi, Sabha, Sirte and Tunis). The security risk assessment for each location governs the vehicles’ usage at each location;

(g)	The vehicle holdings for UNMHA are higher than the standard allocation by 122.7 per cent, which reflects the operational requirement for a pool of vehicles to support convoy movements between Hudaydah and Sana’a and between Aden and southern districts;

(h)	The vehicle holdings for BINUH are 14.0per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to: (i) the operational requirement to have a pool of duty vehicles for medical, security, information technology and engineering personnel to enable them to quickly respond to emergencies; (ii) the need for frequent maintenance and repair caused by poor road conditions and the extensive time needed for repairs at outsourced workshops; and (iii) the need for vehicles to conduct driver testing;

(i)	The vehicle holdings for UNAMA are 59.8 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to: (i) the operational requirement for a pool of vehicles for Kabul to provide dispatch transportation for all staff in the Mission; (ii) provision of airport shuttle services; and (iii) vehicles to conduct driver testing;

The total proposed computing device holdings for special political missions are 7.7per cent higher than the standard allocation. Explanations for computing device holdings that are higher than the standard allocation in specific missions are as follows:

(a)	The computing device holdings at the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen are 6.3 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to requirements for conference and meeting rooms, security monitoring systems, and servers;

(b)	The computing device holdings at UNOWAS are 9.2 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to additional holdings required to provide for training purposes, conference and meeting rooms, and the CarLog system;

(e)	The computing device holdings for United Nations support for the Cameroon-Nigeria Mixed Commission are 20.0 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to additional holdings required to provide for training and meeting rooms;

(i)	The computing device holdings for UNSMIL are 13.2 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to requirements for the CarLog system, data transmission and connectivity and servers;

(j)	The computing device holdings at  the United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia are 8.7 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to requirements for training purposes, internet booths and servers;
(k)	The computing device holdings at UNMHA are 8.7 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to requirements for training purposes, the CarLog system and servers;
(l)	The computing device holdings at BINUH are 3.3 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to requirements for training purposes and servers; and

(m)	The computing device holdings at UNAMA are 11.5 per cent higher than the standard allocation, which is attributable to additional holdings required to provide for training purposes, the CarLog system and servers, as well as provision for other personnel, including contractors.

The holdings are influenced by factors such as the need to provide for consultants and individual contractors, training facilities, Internet booths, information technology maintenance services, CarLog systems, programming of radios and fieldwork. Furthermore, based on the lessons learned during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, which saw a substantial increase in the use of virtual communications and remote working, it is critical to ensure the reliability of information technology equipment and infrastructure and their accessibility to all personnel, both staff and non-staff, to enable business continuity, mandate delivery and the safety and security of staff members, especially in the harsh environments where many special political missions operate.
10.	Air operations

The Secretariat has taken measures to seek efficiencies, as further detailed in paragraph 120 below, and enhance the utilization of the air fleets, with guidance provided to guide staff in field missions with the requisite technical and operational oversight. The portfolio of standby air solutions, which include standby charter agreements, standby air ambulance services, standby aircraft services under letters of assist and other short-term agreements, aims to increase the Secretariat’s agility and responsiveness by addressing among others, urgent requests for ad hoc requirements and provide improved, efficient and timely support. In addition, arrangements for the inter-mission sharing of aircraft provide a sustainable and cost-effective way of doing business, based on a “pay for utilization” modality, when feasible, and excludes fixed costs that are otherwise payable under the dedicated aircraft service agreement.

In 2025, the total resources approved for air operations for the continuing missions amount to $35.7 million, with planned utilization of approximately 5,759 flight hours (4,174 for fixed-wing aircraft and 1,585 for rotary-wing aircraft). In 2026, an amount of $33.4 million is proposed for a total of 4,485 flight hours (3,154 for fixed-wing aircraft and 1,331 for rotary-wing aircraft), Resource requirements for air operations in seven missions (UNOWAS, UNTMIS, UNSMIL, the Verification Mission in Colombia, UNMHA and UNAMA) represent 97.3 per cent of the overall air operation resource requirements for 2026.

In 2026, the proposed resources for air operations represent a decrease of $2.4 million, or 6.6 per cent, compared with 2025, while the flight hours proposed for 2025 represent a reduction of 1,274 hours, or 22.1 per cent, compared with 2025. The above-mentioned decrease reflects an estimated efficiency of $0.7 million based on the new budgetary policy in line with historical flight hour utilization rates mostly for UNOWAS, UNOCA, UNMHA and UNSMIL. In addition, the decrease is the result of: (a) the non-provision of resources for air operations in the liquidation of UNAMI as the current aircraft contract will be discontinued in 2025;  and (b) reduced requirements in UNAMA due to lower fuel consumption rate, reflecting lower estimated volume of 411,500 litres of fuel for the replacement aircraft at an average price of $1.318 per litre, compared with 904,000 litres at an average price of $1.291 per litre in the approved budget for 2025, offset by higher rental and operational costs, in connection with the proposed replacement of the B-1900D fixed-wing aircraft with a SAAB-340B at a higher contractual price. The decrease is offset in part by increased requirements for the United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia based on the latest contractual prices for helicopters with increased guaranteed fleet costs, and to additional flight hours for fixed-wing and rotary-wing aircraft and related aviation fuel necessary to support broader mandate implementation in the locations outside Bogota and ensure connectivity between locations.
11.	Travel
The total resources proposed for official travel amount to $11.4 million, reflecting a decrease of $1.0 million or 7.7 per cent, compared with the approved budget of $12.4 million for 2025.

For 2026, the travel plans are based on the principle that official travel will be undertaken only where it cannot be substituted by other means of communication, including videoconferencing. For the sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, the proposed budget for official travel of staff for 2026 takes into account the frequency of travel by the Chairs of relevant sanctions committees to countries and regions relevant to their respective sanctions’ regime, which requires support from Secretariat staff. The proposed budget for all sanctions expert groups or panels not based in New York provides for one trip by one Secretariat staff member to the relevant region to assist the Chair and/or the group or panel, as well as two trips by one staff member to assist the group or panel during the drafting of interim or midterm and final reports. In addition, the proposed budget for three of the groups or panels that are not based in New York includes one more trip by two Secretariat staff to a country relevant to the sanctions regime to conduct Security Council-mandated sanctions assessment missions.

The programme plans of the special political missions, as presented in the proposed programme budget under the thematic clusters, provide further information on how special political missions have incorporated good practices and increased the use of technology in their work, while also reflecting upon the challenges experienced where technology meets its limits and in-person travel is needed to meet demand and fill coverage gaps. Travel to provide good offices and mediation, conduct fact-finding and monitoring activities, verify compliance and conduct outreach, as well as provide training or capacity-building to national and local partners, remains an indispensable tool in carrying out the work of the special political missions in 2026.

With respect to the performance of special political missions against the 16-day advance purchase policy, the missions are fully aware of the observations and recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions with respect to the need to put measures in place to enhance performance. The overall performance of all special political missions has improved from 28 per cent in 2023 to 39 per cent in 2024. This improvement reflected the efforts across the Secretariat including regular reminders to missions of their responsibility for monitoring real-time performance against the advance purchase policy using corporate dashboards, and to investigate performance drivers and solutions. As noted in the Secretary-General’s latest report on Standards of accommodation for air travel (A/79/628), key performance drivers across the Secretariat are: late submission of travel requests, travel requests that were not “right the first time” and require rework adding to processing time, travel by “external” travelers such as meeting participants and external experts that the Secretariat has less administrative control over, and circumstances outside of the entities’ control such as travel document delays or operational issues including emergencies/exigency of service.

Full compliance with the policy also depends on external factors specific to special political missions. Such factors encompass frequent shifts in mission security and political environments; the necessity to respond to sudden or escalating crises; interruptions arising from distinct logistical arrangements for travel that require special flights or escorts, leading to last-minute bookings for commercial travel; last-minute requests for revisions to meeting schedules and participant lists with multiple stakeholders, such as regional Governments, intergovernmental partners and civil society organizations, outside the control of missions and often at short notice; and late notifications from the organizers of training and learning activities.

While further efforts are still needed, there was a continued improvement in 2024. The overall performance for all special political missions increased from 18 per cent in 2019, 22 per cent in 2020, 21 per cent in 2021, 27 per cent in 2022, 28 per cent in 2023 and 39 per cent in 2024. For the 37 continuing special political missions, 22 missions (representing 59 per cent of the missions) have shown improved performance rates in 2024 as compared with 2023.
12.	Expert panels for recruitment for generic job openings

Recruitment from rosters enables timely recruitment while giving due consideration to organizational imperatives on gender parity and geographical diversity in the interest of having qualified and diverse candidates available to deploy quickly to achieve field mission mandates. Expert panels established pursuant to the administrative instruction on the staff assessment system (ST/AI/2010/3/Rev.3) are an integral part of the roster-based recruitment system. The expert panels assess and recommend candidates who have applied for generic job openings for posts in field missions in order to reduce the administrative burden on individual hiring managers and enhance the quality, consistency and integrity of the recruitment process by centralizing the assessment. They also assist the Human Resources Services Division in the Department of Operational Support in undertaking the assessment of applicants for generic job openings. Expert panels are similar in constitution to an assessment panel and will continue to convene in 2026 to assess and recommend candidates who have applied for generic job openings for positions in the field. As outlined in the administrative instruction on the staff selection system, the expert panels are normally comprised of at least three members, with two being subject matter experts at the same or higher level of the job opening, at least one being a woman and one being from outside the work unit where the job opening is located, who will undertake the assessment of applicants for a job opening. Roster selections are a proven tool to reduce recruitment timelines and front-load a fair assessment process. In 2024, 76 per cent of selections for international positions (FS-4 to D-1) in field missions (special political missions and peacekeeping operations) were from rosters, compared to the rate 50 percent in the global UN Secretariat for roster selections.

In 2026, the Department of Operational Support will continue to enablee roster-based recruitment and manage generic job openings with a view to establishing new rosters that reflect gender balance, geographical diversity and multilingualism. With the upcoming amendment to the staff selection policy, the Department will support the transition to a new global rostering approach and will work with the various departments in the global secretariat and their experts to replenish rosters according to workforce planning requirements, support and development of rosters that will enable entities to meet their human resources strategic imperatives.

text: II.	Analysis of resource requirements for special political missions

children.text: A.	Budget formulation: efforts, methodology and presentation
1.	Building and strengthening a culture of efficiency

Special political missions constitute a major part of the programme budget and expenditure, accounting for previously approximately 20 to 22 per cent of the entire regular budget since 2010. With the termination of the mandates of UNITAMS and UNITAD and the upcoming drawdown of UNAMI and UNTMIS, the proposed budget for special political missions for 2026 accounts for approximately 17 per cent of the regular budget.

The Secretariat continues its efforts to deepen its commitment to cost-efficiency and cost-effectiveness in the request for and utilization of budgetary resources. In January 2025, the Secretariat officially launched its strategic approach to building and strengthening its culture of efficiency in the management of support entities and mission resources, with the aim of transforming the current system of discrete efficiency initiatives into a global, coherent, systematic and consistent approach. This initiative was inaugurated at a Secretary-General’s seminar with all Special Representatives of the Secretary-General of peacekeeping and special political missions, as well as Personal and Special Envoys of the Secretary-General, which was also attended by the Under-Secretaries-General for Operational Support, Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance, Peace Operations and Political and Peacebuilding Affairs.

This strategic approach is intended to ensure that: (a) efficiency considerations (and quantitative benchmarks) are included in relevant mission and Headquarters strategies, policies, assessments, budgets and plans; (b) every staff member in every mission is imbued with a deep commitment to being an effective mandate implementer and custodian of the resources provided by Member States; (c) nurturing such sensitivity in people and programmes is reinforced by those in leadership positions, supported by well-developed systems and processes in place to promote adherence to a culture of efficiency; and (d) cost-efficiencies are realized for Member States on a yearly basis in all budget proposals.

To this end, in formulating the 2026 budget, the Field Operations Finance Division of the Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance enhanced its policy guidance to assist missions in identifying opportunities of efficiency in operations and resource optimization. A list of good practices and potential areas that could generate further efficiency was shared with missions to encourage them to review and broaden the scope of efficiency measures to the various groups of expenditure. This include considering repurposing vacant/long vacant posts with the same mandate delivery/output. Missions were also requested to identify cost avoidance and cost reductions, which will involve a proactive action taken to avoid future expenses, such as inter-mission transfer of assets.

The quantifiable savings and costs avoided amounted to approximately $9.3 million in 2025, representing 1.3 per cent of the 2024 appropriation. At the time of budget formulation, as missions gained experience in strengthening the culture of efficiency, the collective ambition for 2026 was to improve on this performance and aim for 2 per cent in efficiency savings against 2025 appropriations for the continuing mission, excluding UNAMI, representing $11.9 million.

The quantifiable savings and costs avoided amount to approximately $12.7 million in 2026, representing 2.1 per cent of the 2025 appropriation for the continuing missions (additional information is provided in table 4). The major management improvements and efficiency measures applied, and efforts to achieve sustained cost reductions and cost avoidance are reflected in the following areas: (a) the proposed closure of two field offices, the centralization of the country security radio room and the downward reclassification of some posts in UNAMA; (b) cost avoidance related to the non-acquisition of vehicles or equipment owing the transfer of assets from closing missions in BINUH, UNSCOL and UNOWAS; (c) the repurposing of long vacant posts in various missions; (d) the safe, efficient and sustainable fleet services by using the UN Fleet lease contract for the soft-skin fleet the UN Verification Mission in Colombia;  (e) renegotiation of various contracts at lower cost in UNMHA; (f) optimization of the utilization of aircraft, resulting in a reduction in flight hours, without affecting the implementation of its mandate.

Most missions are also reducing the proposed resources for official travel and encouraging instead the use of virtual meetings where feasible, optimizing travel schedules, coordinating with partners to maximize impact while minimizing costs and prioritizing the use of online training options. The number of external consultants has also been reduced to promote the use of in-house capacity to perform core activities. The budgets also reflect economies of scale vis-à-vis the provision of materials and services and substantive support as part of its mandated activities in the context of various cost-sharing arrangements.

children.text: To achieve cost-efficiency and accommodate reduced editorial, translation and text-processing time, as well to enhance readability, the Field Operations Finance Division continued its effort to streamline all budget reports for 2026, achieving a reduction of 14 per cent in the overall document length of the six addenda for special political missions, including the shortening by 30 per cent of the present report (while additional tables and annexes continue to be included in the supplementary information packages for legislative bodies).
2.	    Improved budgeting methodologies

The formulation stage of budget proposals provides an important opportunity to focus attention on issues of cost-efficiency and resource requirements for effective mandate delivery. With the Controller’s budget instructions, the Field Operations Finance Division of the Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance is enhancing its policy guidance to assist missions in appropriately budgeting for their requirements. Where necessary, further assistance was provided to missions in fine-tuning their proposals.

This year, a new comprehensive aviation budgeting policy was developed, as was done for the peacekeeping missions, which includes a data-driven approach for budgeting flight hours. Missions were requested to carefully review the requirements for their air assets and to maximize opportunities for the sharing of air assets across missions, with the support of the Department of Operational Support. In terms of flight hours, missions that utilized 90 per cent or more of the number of flight hours approved for the most recent performance period (2024) can propose maintaining the same number of flight hours approved for that performance period in the relevant categories (rotary or fixed-wing). For missions that utilized less than 90 per cent of the approved flight hours, the proposed flight hours are based on the higher of the average utilization percentage of the three most recent performance periods (2022, 2023 and 2024) and the utilization percentage of the most recent performance period (2024). The higher of those two percentages is then applied to the number of flight hours approved for the most recent performance period (2024) to obtain the proposed flight hours. Limited exceptions to this guidance may be considered on a case-by-case basis, should compelling justifications be provided. To provide missions with flexibility for their operating environment, total flight hours according to the policy may be distributed between the categories as required by the mission. A delayed deployment of 50 per cent is applied for new aircraft, with exceptions considered for the significant reconfiguration of an aviation fleet.

To strengthen oversight of ICT projects and activities and related resource requirements, the budget proposals from the special political missions underwent review and technical clearance by the Office of Information and Communications Technology. The process aims to ensure strategic planning, align demand plan with budget proposals and implementation, avoid duplication of efforts and maximize efficiencies.

To engender more realistic budget proposals, review was also undertaken to reflect relevant historical consumption and utilization patterns based on data-driven approach in the context of the current financial situation. Missions are requested to not only consider their stock levels and pattern of expenditures but to also carefully analyse cancellations of prior-year obligations, which provide another useful indicator of a mission’s implementation capacity.

To strengthen coherence, the proposed post actions adhere consistently to the definitions pertaining to changes in staffing and the proposals are fully justified in terms of changes in mandates or operational circumstances and workload.

In addition, the Secretariat has ensured that all general temporary assistance positions are fully justified under the respective missions, providing the reasons for the proposed retention in 2026. In addition, no proposals have been made to convert these positions to regular posts. Should future assessment lead to a determination that such capacities should be regularized, proper proposals will be made in future budgets.

The practice of presenting New York-based and Geneva-based General Service staff as "international staff", which differentiated between staff in the General Service categories primarily based at Headquarters in New York and Geneva, and those recruited locally in field missions has been discontinued. To ensure consistency reporting for peace operations, the presentation of the New York-based and Geneva-based General Service staff has been realigned, to be reflected under national staff. The application of this standardized categorization would allow all General Service staff resources to be captured under the same budget class, rather than being split across international and national staff, which has required a manual process in the past.
3.	Consistent application of the latest standard rates

With regard to international staff costs in field locations, the budgetary rates for net salary and staff assessment for 2026 were determined for each grade level and for each special political mission according to the following methodology:

(a)	With regard to international staff, the most recent salary scale, effective 1 January 2025 as approved by the General Assembly in its resolution 79/252, was used for net salary and staff assessment for each level in the Professional and higher categories. Similarly, the net base salary scale for staff in the Field Service category is adjusted effective as from 1 January 2025 (as per the standing practice in line with the ICSC decision contained in A/45/30, para. 270 (e);
(b)	The step levels selected for each grade are based on the actual average step levels for each mission as at 31 December 2024, using actual incumbency data for international staff;
(c)	The post adjustment multiplier for each duty station as of April 2025 was applied to the net base salary rates.

With regard to national staff, the most recent salary scales as of April 2025 were used for net salary and staff assessment, with common staff costs as a percentage of net salaries, based on actual expenditure for the period from 1 January to 31 December 2024, applied to the average grade and step of national staff.

With regard to common staff costs, the actual expenditure from 1 January to 31 December 2024 was used to calculate common staff costs as a percentage of net salaries (inclusive of post adjustment but net of staff assessment) to determine the percentage of common staff costs for 2026.

For United Nations Headquarters, offices away from Headquarters and the regional commission duty stations (New York, Geneva, Nairobi, Addis Ababa, Bangkok and Beirut), the standard costs for salaries and common staff costs for the programme budget were used, which were adjusted to reflect the post adjustment multiplier as of April 2025 for those locations.

With regard to military contingents (United Nations Guard Units), the latest single rate of reimbursement to countries contributing contingent personnel to United Nations field operations in the amount of $1,448 per person per month effective 1 July 2022, and the recreation leave allowance of $11.50 per day for up to 15 days of leave taken during each six-month period, as approved by the General Assembly in its resolutions 76/274 and 76/276, were applied. Reimbursement related to contingent-owned equipment are based on the rates adopted by the Assembly in its resolution 77/303.

With regard to military advisers, observers, United Nations police and government-provided personnel, the latest applicable mission subsistence allowance rates for each country and mission area effective from 1 January 2025 were applied, as per the rates promulgated by the Office of Human Resources in December 2024 (OHR/PG/2024/6).

With regard to experts, the estimates considered the latest fee ranges issued by the Office of Human Resources (OHR) (OHR/PG/2025/2). The cost-of-living allowance for non-home-based experts in the Security Council sanctions committee panels and other support mechanisms, the latest monthly rates of $6,600 (New York) and $4,800 (Nairobi) as approved by the Office of Human Resources, which took effect from 1 March 2023, have been applied to the four missions that have such requirements.

With regard to rental of premises in New York, the latest unit rate of $15,000 per person per year, effective as of 1 January 2025, has been applied to those missions accommodated on the Headquarters premises in New York.

With respect to fuel costs, the average price per litre for the different types of fuel in the six-month period from October 2024 to March 2025 have been used as the basis for calculating the provisions for fuel costs under the respective budget classes for 2026.
For information and communications technology, the budget proposals also reflect the latest standard rates and service charges issued by OICT.
4.	Standardized methodology of budgeted vacancy rates

The Field Operations Finance Division provided guidance to all special political missions to improve the accuracy and consistency of the vacancy rate factors applied in the proposed budgets for 2026, to ensure that the proposed vacancy rates are based, as much as possible, on actual rates.

The proposed vacancy rates applied in the budget for 2026, for all types of personnel, have taken into account the experience to date. The assumptions considered for the proposed vacancy rates include the 12-month average vacancy rate in 2024 and the actual vacancy rate as at 31 March 2025. The lower of the two was used as the budgeted vacancy rate.

For proposed establishment of new posts or positions, or posts or positions proposed for reassignment, a vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied in the calculation of costs of such posts. In addition, a vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been used for posts proposed for conversion.

In addition, all special political missions were requested to take into full consideration the recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions and requests from the General Assembly that vacant posts and positions should be filled expeditiously. While efforts continue to fill vacant posts as expeditiously as possible, the current liquidity situation also requires careful planning of recruitment and onboarding to minimize the financial impacts.

The Field Operations Finance Division provided guidance to all special political missions to take the opportunity offered during the preparation of the 2026 budget to critically review long-vacant posts with a view to abolishing vacant posts that can be covered by existing capacities, or to propose reassignment or abolishment with the aim of facilitating the establishment of another function to address a more critical need, or to propose conversion to a national post.

Information on all posts vacant for more than two years and posts encumbered through special post allowances for more than one year is included in the supplementary information under each thematic cluster, which details the vacancy or special post allowance start dates, level and functional title of the posts, organizational unit and current status of recruitment, and provides justification for the retention of long-vacant posts.
5.	Improved presentation of the financial performance

In response to the recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (A/79/7/Add.1, paragraph 10) and the request of the General Assembly in it resolution 79/258 A, the Secretariat is continuing to its efforts to enhance the financial performance reporting of the special political missions in the context of the present report, the financial performance report of the programme budget, and the supplementary information provided for the special political missions. To this end, more comprehensive and detailed information on the financial performance is being provided, by mission and by budget class, including information on unliquidated obligations and the cancellation of prior-period obligations, as provided in table 6 below. In addition, for air operations, mine actions and construction projects for field-based special political missions under thematic cluster III, UNAMA and UNAMI information has been included in the supplementary information for those missions, similar to for peacekeeping operations, in response to the recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (see A/78/7/Add.1, para. 56).

Additional information on the evolution of financial resources by mission over the most recent five years is provided in table 11 of the present report. Additional information on the evolution of financial resources for each mission, broken down by budget class, over that period, including both appropriation and expenditure, is provided in the supplementary information for each thematic cluster (including UNAMA and UNAMI), similar to the rest of the regular budget, in response to the recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (see A/78/7, para. 7).

In response to the recommendation of the Advisory Committee (A/79/7/Add.1, paragraph 13), endorsed by the General assembly in its resolution 79/258 A, additional information on the liquidation activities for UNITAD and UNITAMS has been included in the reports of the Secretary-General for the missions grouped under cluster II and cluster III, with more detailed information included in the supplementary information packages.
B.	Financial resources
Analysis of financial performance of special political missions

The General Assembly approved an overall appropriation of $742.0 million for the special political missions (resolutions 78/254 A–C and 78/274). The expenditure for 2024 amounted to $682.5 million, resulting in an overall unencumbered balance of $59.5 million or 8.0 per cent. The overall implementation rate in 2024 was lower than in previous years owing to the spending restrictions imposed due to the liquidity constraints and the efforts to curtail expenditures across special political missions, with under-expenditure representing 8.0 per cent of the appropriation, compared with under-expenditure representing 2.3 per cent of the appropriation in 2023. An analysis of the main factors affecting budget performance is provided in table 5. The performance reporting has been enhanced through the inclusion of information for field-based missions in the Financial Performance Report for 2024 (A/80/89), in line with the recommendation of the ACABQ in A/79/7/Add.1, para 10. Further details are also included in the supplementary information under each thematic cluster.
Table 5 – Main factors affecting budget performance in 2024

table_content.text: Military and police personnel (underexpenditure of $1.4 million)

The variance was attributable primarily to: (a) a lower-than-planned deployment of United Nations police officers in BINUH; (b) lower costs for rations due to the use of existing stock reserve and lower-than-estimated costs for the rotation of the UN Guard Unit  in UNSOM/UNTMIS; (c) lower-than-estimated costs for the rotation of military contingent personnel and lower requirements for rations in UNAMI; and (d) lower- than- estimated requirements claims for death and disability compensation. The underexpenditure was offset in part by additional expenditure for military observers in the Verification Mission in Colombia attributable to a higher-than-planned deployment of observers and an increase in the mission subsistence allowance rates.

The variance was attributable primarily to higher-than-budgeted common staff costs, and higher-than-budgeted salaries due to higher-than-estimated post adjustment multipliers for international staff, updated salary scales for national staff and updated living allowances for United Nations Volunteers, which was offset in part by the higher-than-budgeted average vacancy rates as a result of hiring restrictions.

The variance reflects the austerity measures implemented to contain expenditures as well as lower-than-budgeted consumptions in certain areas, attributable primarily to: (a) lower requirements for facilities and infrastructure in UNSOM/UNTMIS, UNAMA, UNAMI, the Verification Mission in Colombia and BINUH; (b) reduced requirements for air operations in UNMHA, UNSMIL, UNAMI, UNAMA, and UNOWAS; (c) reduced requirements for communications and information technology owing to curtailed maintenance and support services, and the suspension of public information and publication services for planned outreach events: (d) postponed  acquisition of equipment, supplies and spare parts with the related reduced in freight costs; (e) cancellation of planned  official travel; (f) suspension of planned workshops and retreats, and (g) reduced requirements for experts due to the vacancies in some panels of experts and mechanisms supporting sanctions and the expiration of the mandate for the Panel of Experts in support of the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1718 (2006).

Proposed resources for 2026

The total proposed resource requirements for 2026 relating to the 37 special political missions covered in the present report amount to $639.8 million net of staff assessment and inclusive of the provision for the share of special political missions in the budget of the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe. Overall, the resource level for 2026 reflects a decrease of $53.2 million, including the impact of closing missions (with a decrease of 495 posts and positions) compared with the appropriation for 2025. children.text: Variance analysis – Cluster I

The proposed resource requirements for the 11 missions under cluster I for 2026 amount to $52.1 million, representing a net increase of $5.1 million (10.8 per cent) compared with 2025. The overall increase attributable primarily to: (a) increased requirements for civilian personnel owing to the application of updated vacancy rates and revised salary rates; and (b) increased requirements under facilities and infrastructure for rental of premises for the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Syria for new office space in Damascus in compliance with the Minimum Operating Security Standards. The increase was offset in part by: (a) the removal of provisions for rental of a passenger charter plane and services provided by UNOG for meetings of the international Syria Support Group and sessions of the Constitutional Committee for the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Syria; (b) reduced requirements for official travel in several missions; and (c) and reduced requirements for ground transportation for the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen owing to the discontinuation of fuel reserve in Aden and Sana’a.
Cluster II

The proposed resource requirements for the 14 continuing missions under cluster II for 2026 amount to $38.0 million, representing a net increase of $0.7 million (1.9 per cent) compared with 2025. The overall increase is attributable primarily to: (a) increased requirements for expert fees owing to the issuance of new fee ranges by the Office of Human Resources (OHR) (OHR/PG/2025/2); (b) higher estimates for common staff costs based on recent expenditure experience of staff entitlements; and (c) the application of lower vacancy rates for civilian personnel. The increase was offset in part by: (a) reduced requirements for telecommunications and network services owing to reduced provision of subscription to the emergency satellite communicator service  and removal of the provision for satellite telephone data and video conference services based on utilization patterns; (b) the application of the latest reduced standard rate for communications and information technology (ICT) for New York; and (c) the proposed abolishment of two posts as part of the effort of the Security Council Subsidiary Organs Branch of Security Council Affairs Division to find efficiencies within its staffing levels by levering technology and consolidation of functions. The resources reflect the expiration of mandate in October 2025 of the mission supporting the Implementation of Security Council resolution 2231 (2015), for which provision was made for 10 months in 2025.
Cluster III

The proposed resource requirements for the 10 missions under cluster III for 2026 amount to $384.1 million, representing a net decrease of $1.1 million (0.3 per cent) compared with 2025. The overall decrease is attributed to: (a) the planned drawdown of UNTMIS and adjustment made to mission activities and services to cover only 10-month period up to 31 October 2026, in accordance with second phase of the mission transition as outlined in Security Council Resolution 2753 (2024); and proposed abolishment of 11 posts as at 1 January 2026; (b) reduced requirements for National Professional Officers due to the application of higher vacancy rates and the abolishment of two posts in UNMHA; (c) the application of higher vacancy rates for United Nations police officers in BINUH; (d) lower requirements for ground transportation due to reduced rental costs in the UN Verification Mission in Colombia with the implementation of the UN Fleet lease contract for the soft-skin fleet; (e) reduced requirements for communications and information technology equipment and its maintenance; and (f) reduced requirements for consultants owing to the higher reliance on in-mission expertise in UNOWAS and the UN Verification Mission in Colombia, as well lower estimates for travel and scope for civilian observers for CNMC. The decrease was offset in part additional requirements: (a) for military observers owing to an increase in the  mission subsistence allowance rates and the applications of lower vacancy rates in UNMHA and the UN Verification Mission in Colombia; (b) for air operations in the UN Verification Mission in Colombia to support broader mandate implementation in the locations outside Bogota and ensure connectivity between location; and (c) for facilities and infrastructure for the construction of a new road and parking area, fuel station, construction of the infrastructure networks and other security enhancements in UNSMIL.
United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan

The proposed resource requirements for UNAMA for 2026 amount to $124.5 million, representing a net decrease of $0.2 million (0.2 per cent) compared with the 2025 appropriation. attributable to reduced requirements for civilian personnel, owing mainly to the abolishment of 117 posts and the application of a higher vacancy rate for international staff, offset by higher requirements for United Nations Volunteer costs owing to a lower vacancy rate and higher entitlement costs, as well as the proposed establishment of 18 new posts.  The decrease in requirements is offset in part by increased requirements for operational costs, attributable primarily to additional requirements for: (a) construction of a central warehouse for more efficient space management and for the improvement of the wastewater treatment plant and the compound facilities including for security upgrade; and (b) acquisition of safety and security equipment as well as the replacement of prefabricated accommodations and equipment, and engineering supplies required for the general maintenance of the compounds and to support the planned minor projects.
Liquidation of the United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq

The proposed resource requirements for the liquidation of UNAMI for 2026 amount to $38 million for the orderly liquidation of the Mission, representing a net decrease of $57.4 million (60.1 per cent) compared with the 2026 appropriation. The budget provides for the phased separation of the liquidation team of 135 existing posts to be retained into 2026, with the majority of the staff separating on 30 September 2026. In addition, provision is made for surge capacity from the Department of Operational Support and the United Nations Logistics Base at Brindisi, Italy, to assist with the liquidation activities.
Share of the cost of the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe

The share of special political missions for the cost of the Regional Service Centre reflects an increase of $33,200, attributable mainly to an increase of the share of special political missions in the cost of the Centre, from 4.99 per cent in the 2024/25 period to 5.10 cent in the 2025/26 period. This reflects the addition of the Office of the Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Sudan as a client and the decrease in the Peacekeeping missions pro-rated share due to the closure of MINUSMA.

The estimated resource requirements of $46.3 million for the maintenance of the Centre for the 2025/26 financial period represent a decrease of $1.7 million, or 3.5 per cent, compared with the approved resources of $48.0 million for the 2024/25 period. The proposed budget reflects reduced requirements due primarily to the transfer of 42 posts (40 from current tenant units reporting to DOS, and two seconded military planning officer posts reporting to DPO) to the budgets of their parent offices in the support account. The reduced requirements are offset in part by (a) the application of lower vacancy rates for international, national professional and national general service staff compared to the vacancy rates applied in the approved budget for the 2024/25 period (b) the application of higher salary rates for national staff, (c) the application of updated exchange rate for the Ugandan shilling to the United States dollar, and (d) an increase in operational costs mainly for safety and security unit requirements; and higher rates for new systems contracts.

The decrease is offset in part by: (a) to the application of the revised salary rates and higher estimated common staff costs  (common staff costs as a percentage of salary costs of 56.9 per cent compared to 50.4 per cent in the 2025 budget) based on past expenditure for international staff; (b) the application of a lower vacancy rate of zero per cent compared to the rate of 12.5 per cent approved for 2025 for national staff; and (c) higher estimated costs for the rental of premises and utilities for the office collocated with UNOWAS in Abuja, Nigeria.
Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon

The increase is attributable mainly to: (a) the proposed establishment of five posts; (b) the application of a lower vacancy rate of 5.0 per cent compared to the rate of 6.7 per cent approved for 2025 for national staff; (c) the replacement of prefabricated and security equipment that are beyond their useful life, and increased requirements for rental costs and small alternation and renovation projects to meet the growing operational demands and enhance working environment; (c) increased requirements for communication and information technology to replace critical, obsolete equipment and assets that have exceeded their life expectancy, as well as additional resources for public information services as part of a broader strategy to promote the implementation of resolution 1701; and (d) higher estimated freight costs for the equipment to be acquired. The increase is offset in part by lower requirements for international staff due to the application of revised salary rates; and the non-provisioning of resources for consultants and consulting services.

The increase is attributable mainly to: (a) the application of a lower vacancy rate of 12.1 per cent compared to the rate of 20.2 per cent in the approved budget for 2025 for international staff; and (b) the application of the most recent salary scale for Local Level; which is offset in part by reduced requirements for air operations in line with historical  flight hour utilization rates; and the non-provisioning of resources for individual contractual services.

The decrease in requirements is attributable mainly to: (a) reduced requirements for civilian personnel, owing to the application of a 100 per cent vacancy rate to 35 posts vacant for more than 3 years, offset by the application of lower vacancy rates, and the application of lower continuing vacancy rates for the eight positions that were approved for establishment in 2025 and budgeted with a vacancy rate of 50 per cent; (b) reduced requirements for air operations in line with historical  flight hour utilization rates; and (c) reduced requirements for the United Nations Guard Unit personnel, owing to the non-requirement for rations due to anticipated stock availability from prior period procurement, as well as the removal of a provision for death and disability compensation following a review of historical expenditure pattern. The decrease is offset in part by increased requirements under: (a) due to additional requirements for the construction of a new road and parking area, fuel station, construction of the infrastructure networks and other security enhancements. in connection with Phase 2 of the planned security enhancements works in the Mission’s compound; and (b) new requirements for the quick-impact projects.
United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia

The increase is attributable mainly to: (a) increased requirements for military observers due to the increase in the mission subsistence allowance rates and the application of lower vacancy rates; (b) additional requirements for international United Nations Volunteers due to increased monthly living allowance; (c) increased requirements for air operations due to a change in contractual arrangements, and to additional flight hours to support broader mandate implementation in the locations outside Bogota and ensure connectivity between locations; and (d) additional riverine activities to cover an enlarged mission area especially the locations that are not accessible by ground or air transportation. The increase is offset in part by: (a) lower estimated common staff costs (estimated common staff costs as a percentage of salary costs of 51.7 per cent compared to 56.8 per cent in the 2025 budget) for international staff; (b) the application of higher vacancy rates for National Professional Officers and national General Service staff; (c) reduced requirements for consultants owing to the higher reliance on in-mission expertise; (d) lower estimated costs for the rental of premises and non-acquisition of furniture; (e) lower estimated costs for rental of vehicles (f) fewer acquisition of communication and information technology equipment; (g) lower requirements for medical services; and (h)  lower requirements for freight due to fewer acquisition.

The decrease is attributable mainly to: (a) the application of a higher vacancy rate of 27.5 per cent for the 2026 budget proposal compared to 25.4 per cent applied during 2025 for international staff; (b) the application of a higher vacancy rate of 50.0 per cent for 2026 budget proposal compared to 25.8 per cent applied during 2025 National Professional Officers as well as proposed abolishment of two National Professional Officers posts; and (c) reduced rental of premises including for the Mission’s locations in Sana’a and Hudaydah, fewer acquisition of furniture and reduced requirements for generators fuel due to the discontinuation of the respective reserve;. The increase is offset in part by: (a)  an increase in the  mission subsistence allowance rate  and lower vacancy rate for the United Nations monitors: (b)  the  establishment of additional Local level posts and revised salary scales in Amman; (c) increased repairs and maintenance of ground fleet; (d) increased requirements for  aviation of fuel and  airport charges.

The increase is attributable mainly to the application of a lower vacancy rates and revised salary scales for both international and national staff;  increased requirements for facilities and infrastructure due to increased demand for security services; increased requirements under other supplies, services and equipment due to increased demand for the United Nations Humanitarian Air Services flights due lo logistical challenges and cancelation of civil aviation flights, increased freight due to expected receipt of assets from the United Nations reserve. The increase is offset in part by application of a higher vacancy rates for United Nations Police Officers, government-provided personnel and international United Nations Volunteers.

The decrease is attributable to the net reduction of 87 posts and the application of a higher vacancy rate for international staff; which was offset in part by additional requirements for: (a) the construction of a central warehouse for more efficient space management and to upgrade the wastewater treatment plant and the compound facilities including for security enhancements; and (b) acquisition of safety and security equipment as well as the replacement of prefabricated accommodations and equipment, and engineering supplies required for the general maintenance of the compounds and to support the planned minor projects.
The decrease is attributable to the phased drawdown and liquidation of the Mission, in line with Security Council resolution 2732 (2024).
The mission’s mandate is set to expire in October 2025. Provision was made for 10 months in 2025.
Provision for the share of special political missions for the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe

The increase is attributable mainly to an increase of the share of special political missions in the cost of the Centre, from 4.99 per cent in the 2024/25 period to 5.10 in 2025/26, due the addition of the Office of the Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Sudan as an RSCE client and the decreased in the Peacekeeping missions pro-rated share due to the closure of MINUSMA.
