children.text: Abbreviations: ASG, Assistant Secretary-General; FS, Field Service; LL, Local level; NPO, National Professional Officer; OL, Other level; PL, Principal level; USG, Under-Secretary-General.

Note: Posts indicated in table 12 are those funded or projected to be funded from extrabudgetary resources in the current and forthcoming year, based on the latest information available and projections made at the time of reporting. In keeping with established practice, the table does not include extrabudgetary general temporary assistance positions, positions that are billed to a third party or project posts that are not expected to be funded continuously for more than one year.
Terminology related to proposed changes in human resources
The following terms have been applied with respect to proposed changes in human resources:

Post establishment: a new post is proposed to be established when additional resources are necessary and when it is not possible to redeploy resources from other offices or otherwise accommodate specific activities from within existing resources.

Post reassignment: an approved post that was intended to cover a certain function is proposed to implement other priority mandated activities unrelated to the original function. While a post reassignment may involve a change of location or office, it does not change the category or level of the post.
Post redeployment: an approved post is proposed to be redeployed to cover comparable or related functions in another office.
Post reclassification: an approved post is proposed to be reclassified (upgraded or downgraded) when the duties and responsibilities of the post have changed substantially.

Post abolishment: an approved post is proposed to be abolished if it is no longer needed to implement the activities for which it was approved or to implement other priority mandated activities within the mission.
Post conversion: three possible options for post conversion are as follows:

– Conversion of general temporary assistance positions to posts: approved positions financed under general temporary assistance are proposed for conversion to posts if the functions being performed are of a continuing nature.
– Conversion of international staff posts to national staff posts: approved international staff posts are proposed for conversion to national staff posts.

– Conversion of the approved source of funding: positions funded under extrabudgetary resources are proposed for conversion to be funded under the regular budget. Other attributes of the positions would remain unchanged.
Terminology related to variance analysis
The contributing factors for the resource variance according to specific standard options encompass the following categories listed below:
New and expanded mandates: variances caused by changes in the scale or scope of the mandate.

Technical adjustments: variances caused by adjustments caused by increased provisions for posts approved for the preceding budget proposals with a 50 per cent vacancy rate that are subject to the proposed vacancy rate for continuing posts in the current proposed budget period. Other adjustments of a technical nature, include change in salary rates, vacancy rates contractual rates, or other changes in costs parameters caused by United Nations regulations, rules and policies.

Management initiatives and efficiencies: variances caused by management actions to achieve planned results more effectively (e.g. by reprioritizing or adding certain outputs) or efficiently (e.g. by taking measures to reduce personnel or operational inputs while maintaining the same level of outputs).
Other changes: variances caused by resource changes that do not fall under the above factors.

text: Annex II Summary of follow-up action taken to implement decisions and requests made by the General Assembly, including the requests and recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions endorsed by the Assembly

children.text: General Assembly
(Resolution 79/258A)

table_content.text: Action taken to implement the recommendation

Recalls paragraph 10 of the report of the Advisory Committee  and requests the Secretary-General to improve the overall presentation of the financial performance of the special political missions (para. 3).
Information on the efforts of the Secretariat to improve the presentation of   the financial performance is provided is paragraphs 142-147.

Notes with appreciation the initiative to build a culture of efficiency in special political missions which generates accountability, saving and cost avoidance, and reiterates that Member State resources should be managed with utmost efficiency, and requests the Secretary-General to continue to improve the culture of efficiency in both headquarters and field missions, and use a data-driven approach in formulating budgetary requirements, based on mandated activities, and continue to report thereon in future budget submissions (para. 4).

In response to the request of the General Assembly Budget proposals reflect increased efficiencies of 12.7 million (2.1%) for 2026, compared to 9.3 million (1.3%) in 2025, while not affecting the full and effective implementation of mandates, as further detailed in the section on building and strengthening a culture of efficiency and improved budgetary methodologies in (paragraphs 111-118). A strategic approach to a culture of efficiency was also officially launched with all SRSGs and Envoys of the Secretary-General in January 2025.

Requests the Secretary-General to continue to monitor the use of financial resources and to avoid unnecessary rushing expenditure of surplus funds before the end of the fiscal year, while acknowledging that spending progress could be impacted by liquidity management measures (para. 5).

As the Organization continues to face liquidity challenges, the effectiveness of the programme delivery and use of the financial resources depend on the availability of cash. Unless the liquidity reserves are replenished in full, cash conservation measures implemented will likely to constrain budget implementation, notwithstanding the efforts of programme managers to mitigate their negative impact and to commit funds to meet critical needs before the end of the fiscal year.
As per Financial Regulations and Rules, Missions requested to refrain from redeploying unused funds for certain uses within the financial period for last minute purchases or commitments aimed to achieve full budget implementation

Recognizes that patterns of underexpenditure across various budget lines under the ongoing liquidity challenges of the Organization can be linked to limited released allotments, and stresses that this specific type of underexpenditure should not be used to achieve budgetary savings (para. 6).

As per existing practice, the budget proposals in the reports of the Secretary-General for all entities under the regular budget continue to assume that the full budget will be available to implement the mandated activities, i.e. that the proposed budgets are not constrained by liquidity. This does not preclude the efforts of the Secretariat to present realistic budget proposals, that reflect relevant historical consumption and utilization patterns based on data-driven approach in the context of the current financial situation.

Recalls paragraph 13 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and requests the Secretary-General to provide information on liquidation within existing reports in a separate section, as appropriate (para. 7).

Information of the liquidation activities for UNITAD and UNITAMS has been included in the reports of the Secretary-General for the missions grouped under cluster II and cluster III, with more detailed information included in the supplementary information packages.

Also recalls paragraph 36 of the report of the Advisory Committee, notes the progress in the nationalization of international positions in special political missions, and reiterates its request to the Secretary-General to continue his efforts to promote the nationalization of positions, whenever appropriate, as well as to build local capacity within the special political missions and to report thereon in the context of future budget submissions (para. 8).

The section on promoting national capacities (paragraphs 73 to 76) contains information on the efforts that the special political missions continue to promote the nationalization of posts in response to the request of the General Assembly. BINUH is facing significant turnover among national staff with the exodus of professionals from Haiti due to the prevailing security situation. UNAMA continues to evaluate posts for nationalization, taking into consideration the restrictions imposed by the de facto authorities, specifically targeting females, which may create obstacles to certain tasks. UNSMIL continues to engage in initiatives that enhance skills development and capacity-building efforts for national staff, contributing to long-term sustainability beyond the Mission’s presence. Moving forward, missions will continue to explore further opportunities for nationalization, taking into account operational needs, security considerations and the availability of skilled local talent. By fostering national expertise and ownership, missions not only enhance their effectiveness but also contribute to the long-term stability and development of the regions they serve.

Notes the role of in-person engagement for the implementation of the mandates of special political missions, and requests the Secretary-General to make judicious use of resources for official travel (para. 9).

While recognizing the significance of in-person engagement for the effective implementation of mandate, missions are implementing measures to minimize its requirements under official travel including prioritizing the appropriate use of technology to attend virtual meetings, online training and minimizing travel requirements to attend workshops, conferences and meetings. Virtual engagements continue to complement in-person interactions when appropriate, helping to reduce travel frequency without compromising mission effectiveness. In addition, in UNAMA, travel to field offices is restricted to single day travel to reduce the payment for daily subsistence allowance. Efforts have been made by CTED to consolidate travel itineraries, review the size of the delegations, promote regional coordination where feasible, and leverage opportunities for multi-organizational collaboration.

Reiterates its concern about the high number of vacancies, and requests the Secretary-General to fill vacant positions expeditiously, and to conduct a review on how to effectively utilize existing posts, including those that have been vacant for 24 months or longer, and to report the results of the review by proposing either their retention, with clear justification of need, changing of post or proposing their abolishment, as appropriate, in his future reports (para. 10).

The Secretary-General imposed temporary restrictions on hiring to manage the evolving liquidity crisis, which prevented Missions from executing hiring plans.
Missions continue to engage in extensive review to include proposals to abolish long-vacant posts and positions in their budget submissions, when appropriate, demonstrating proactive measures to optimize staffing resources. 
Information on the status of recruitment of long-vacant posts is presented in the supplementary information for each thematic cluster.

Recalls its stipulation that the use of external consultants should be kept to an absolute minimum and that the Organization should utilize its in-house capacity to perform core activities or to fulfil functions that are recurrent over the long term (para. 11).

The use of external consultants has been limited to an absolute minimum in the proposed budgets for 2026. The missions will prioritize the use of in-house capacity to perform core activities and to perform functions over long-term periods in support of successful mandate implementation. In UNTMIS the proposed resources for consultants are dedicated for national staff capacity building to facilitate job seeking and career transitioning for its staff. In UNOCA, the use of internal expertise is prioritized to ensure cost-effectiveness, sustainability, and the retention of institutional knowledge, strengthening the organization's long-term capacity.

Also recalls the provisions of section XVIII of its resolution 61/276 of 29 June 2007, recognizes the important role played by quick-impact projects in establishing and building confidence in missions, also recognizes the importance of conducting assessments of the quick-impact projects regularly, on their needs and impact as required in resolution 61/276, requests the Secretary-General to include the conducted assessments in his next reports, and also requests the Secretary-General to enhance their impact (para. 12).

The use of quick-impact projects has been limited in the majority of the special political missions, which focus on their primary mandate of political engagement, mediation, and support to governance and rule of law, often relying on partnerships with other entities to address immediate community needs.
UNMHA has leveraged quick-impact projects in enhancing its engagement with the parties to the Hudaydah Agreement and focused on thematic areas on women, income generation, education and health sector in designing its quick-impact projects to have the intended impact of confidence and trust building. An impact assessment of the 2023 projects is being conducted in 2025 to review the contributions quick-impact projects have made to progressing the mandate and the tangible benefits they have brought to beneficiaries. The findings and lessons learned from the impact assessment will be used to inform future design and implementation of its projects.
In addition, for 2026, a provision of $50,000 is being proposed for UNSMIL for quick-impact projects to enhance confidence in the Mission’s mandate in supporting the political process, reconciliation and prevention of intra- and inter-community violence.

Further recalls paragraph 56 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and requests the Secretary-General to review the services provided to the existing clients of the Kuwait Joint Support Office and to report thereon in the context of his next report (para. 13).
Information on the review undertaken by the Secretariat is provided in paragraphs 67-70.

Reaffirms its commitment to considering the review of the arrangements on the funding and backstopping of the special political missions and the recommendations of the Advisory Committee, and expresses its commitment to considering this matter, with a view to making a decision, without prejudging the outcome, at the main part of its eightieth session (para. 14).

In accordance with General Assembly resolution 65/259 (sect. XIII, para. 7), in 2011 the Secretary-General submitted a proposal to the Assembly to review the funding and backstopping arrangements for Special Political Missions (A/66/340). Pending a decision of the General Assembly on the matter, as an ad hoc arrangement, resources for backstopping support are included in the budgets of the special political missions. At the present, this remains the only sustainable way of providing backstopping support funded from assessed contributions in the absence of a dedicated mechanism to ensure relevant capacities for backstopping special political missions at Headquarters, in contrast to peacekeeping operations, which can draw on the support account for peacekeeping operations.

Expresses concern about the significant variance between the actual vehicle and computing device holdings and standard allocations in special political missions, and in this regard requests the Secretary-General to update the vehicle holding ratio and related guidance, as well as the computing device allocation ratio, to enable the missions to improve the transparency and accuracy of the relevant budgets (para. 17).

The Standard Cost and Ratio Manual provides guidance to entities related to planning and estimation of operational support resource requirements. In reviewing the vehicle holding ratios, the Secretariat found that a singular ratio for each category that was applicable to all entities was not practicable. The standard ratio for light passenger vehicles for field missions is to be used as a guide when assessing ground transportation needs, subject to the relevance to operations in any given Secretariat entity.
In response to the request of General Assembly to improve transparency and accuracy in computing device allocations in special political missions, the guidelines issued by OICT reinforced the “one computing device per user” policy as a best-practice reference to improve budget discipline, cost-effectiveness, and alignment with Secretariat-wide ICT governance. Individual missions may deviate from the guidelines based on operational requirements. Any requests exceeding standard allocations be accompanied by clear operational justification approved by the Head of Entity.

Welcomes the early issuance of reports, and requests the Secretary-General to continue to present future budget proposals for special political missions, including revised estimates when applicable, at the beginning of the Fifth Committee session in order to allow sufficient time for consideration by the General Assembly (para. 18).

The Secretariat will continue its efforts to set and adhere to submission deadlines of reports to the General Assembly to ensure that the budget proposals are presented at the beginning of the Fifth Committee session to allow sufficient time for consideration by the General Assembly.

Requests the Secretary-General to also include in the Umoja budget portal budget data for special political missions in line with how information is presented in Umoja for peacekeeping operations, and also requests the Secretary-General to strengthen his efforts to provide accurate and precise information in Umoja (para. 19).
In response to the request of the General Assembly, the Secretariat will enhance the use of the Budget Information Portal (BIP) to provide more disaggregated data and statistics from the reports.

Emphasizes the importance of adequate energy and waste management in order to minimize risk to people, societies and ecosystems, and requests the Secretary - General to intensify the efforts aimed at reducing the overall environmental footprint of missions, including through the implementation of environmentally responsible waste management and power generation systems, also working towards a potential positive legacy for host communities, in full compliance with the relevant regulations and rules (para. 20).

Field-based special political missions are included in the scope of the Way Forward: Environment Strategy for Peace Operations 2030 and of the Environmental Policy for Peacekeeping Missions and Field-Based Special Political Missions (DOS 2021). As such, missions are implementing measures to improve energy, solid waste and wastewater management with technical assistance from DOS, and are reporting environmental performance data in the common environmental action planning and performance (eAPP) platform, culminating in the issuance of annual mission environmental scorecards available for Member States. 
In the UN Verification Mission in Colombia, the solar power system planned to be installed during 2025 will generate increased efficiencies in electrical power generation and reduce energy costs and carbon footprint. In BINUH, the installation of a solar power system has enabled since January 2023 to offset 17.2 tons of CO2 emissions into the atmosphere. The Mission started a campaign to prohibit the use of single-use plastics on mission grounds and continued the implementation of vehicle idling policies to save fuel and reduce pollution. To save fuel in Hudaydah, UNMHA has installed a PV-diesel hybrid system that combines solar power from a photovoltaic system with the generators, saving 19 per cent of power consumption and approximately 3,500 litres of fuel per month. The Field Remote Infrastructure Monitoring implemented allow to detect eventual leakages and monitor water and fuel consumption. Other measures implemented by UNMHA and OSESGY include the usage of energy saving efficient LED lights, inverter-type AC units, and motion sensors. UNAMA has wastewater treatment plants to minimize the risk of contaminated water and recycles treated wastewater for gardening purpose, and has also installed Solar Power systems and conserves power through improved management and awareness campaign to minimise the use of fossil fuel, resulting in a reduction of carbon emissions. UNSCOL is working collaboratively with UNIFIL on the environmentally responsible disposal of decommissioned equipment, and prioritizing resource efficiency, including paper recycling and the installation of LED lighting. UNSMIL completed the installation of solar streetlights in the compound in Tripoli with the yearly consumption of 12,300 KWhr and will implement Solar Power projects for the Prefab offices with capacity of 100 KW in 2025; and will continue the Solar Power Project for offices in 2026 to reduce the environmental footprint of the mission. Quarterly beach cleaning campaign is conducted for reducing the environmental footprint on the waste management. The initiatives implemented by UNTMIS included the expansion of the renewable energy base from 9 per cent to 23 per cent following the expansion of solar panels in mission site in Mogadishu and connection of the site at Baidoa to KUBE Solar Power plant, utilization of LED light, efficient Air Conditioners, light motion sensors, and diesel generator synchronization, resulting in an environmental performance of 86%.

Stresses that special political missions and other United Nations entities should identify areas of complementarity and avoid duplication of resources, while carrying out their distinct mandates, including in cooperation with host countries, and encourages the Secretary-General to inform the General Assembly on the efficiencies achieved as a result of this coordination in the context of his next report (para. 21).

Owing to the variety and diversity of special political missions, their cooperation with peacekeeping operations will differ according to the type of mandates that they are requested to perform. Since the reform of the peace and security pillar in 2019, the ability of the Secretariat to ensure close collaboration between all missions operating in a similar region has been significantly strengthened, as they are now backstopped by the shared regional structure of DPPA and DPO at Headquarters. 
Sanctions panels and monitoring groups are mandated to support targeted Security Council sanctions regimes that might pertain to situations in which peacekeeping operations are deployed, such as in the Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of the Congo and South Sudan.
In certain cases, special political missions (including sanctions panels and monitoring groups) with regional mandates may work closely with a country-based special political mission and/or peacekeeping operations to address regional issues that might have an impact in their area of operation. In these cases, ad hoc operational support and the respective recovery/sharing of costs is provided on a need basis, ensuring coordination for transportation, security and other administrative matters.   
By fostering cooperation across the UN system, the Office of the Special Envoy for the Great Lakes seeks to maximize the impact of its work and contribute to greater organizational efficiency. In BINUH the efforts in place to strengthen integration include joint participation by the mission and the United Nations Country Team in the key policymaking and strategy forums, and collaboration through joint programmes and teams in areas including community violence reduction, justice, elections and police reform. 
CTED has continued to coordinate closely with UNOCT and UNODC to ensure distinct but mutually reinforcing roles in supporting Member States' efforts to counter terrorism. Regular inter-agency consultations and information-sharing mechanisms have been institutionalized to align technical assistance, avoid overlapping activities, and maximize the impact of field engagements. 
UNSCOL remains committed to identifying, where feasible, measures and strategies to increase efficiencies and to strengthen synergy and coordination practices with UNIFIL specifically and other UN entities in Lebanon; and receives technical and transactional support from UNIFIL in the areas of finance, procurement, engineering, CIT, medical service, contingency planning, and other logistics as required.	
UNSMIL and United Nations entities conduct joint programmes (Electoral Assistance, The Young Female Training Programme [Ra'idat]), joint coordination activities with government officials through the UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework, and joint analysis through an 'Economic Hub' of UN staff economists.

Requests the Secretary-General to conduct a review on flexible working arrangements in special political missions and report thereon to the General Assembly in the context of his next budget submission (para. 22).

Missions are requested to comply with the provisions outlined in the Secretary-General’s bulletin (ST/SGB/2019/3) and the information circular (ST/IC/2019/15) on flexible working arrangements. In December 2024, additional policy information was issued by the Office of Human Resources to clarify the flexible working arrangements (FWA) and alternate working arrangements (AWA) (OHR/PG/2024/7).
UNSMIL in January 2025 issued an SOP to all Mission personnel on the use of Flexible Working Arrangements and is closely monitoring the use of the benefit in order to ensure consistency with the relevant policy.
In the UN Verification Mission in Colombia, in Bogota, due to space limitations resulting from the merging of two locations into the main building in an effort to control costs, some units must resort to alternate working arrangements, requesting staff to work from home a maximum of two days per week.

Calls upon the Secretary-General to continue his efforts to advance the implementation of the zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation and abuse throughout the United Nations system, including the agencies, funds and programmes, peacekeeping missions and non-United Nations forces authorized by the Security Council (para. 23).

The Secretariat continues to engage with Member States on prioritizing collective efforts to prevent misconduct, applying enforcement measures and supporting and assisting victims affected by acts of misconduct.
Updates on action taken by the Secretariat to strengthen the prevention of and response to sexual exploitation and abuse are provided in the next report of the Secretary-General on special measures for the protection from sexual exploitation and abuse (A/79/789).

Stresses and re-emphasizes that best value for money; fairness, integrity and transparency; effective international competition; and the interest of the United Nations remain the four general principles of United Nations procurement, and requests the Secretary-General to ensure that those principles are adhered to in all United Nations procurement activities (para. 24).
The Secretary-General confirms that the Secretariat remains guided by the four general principles of United Nations Procurement as per Regulation 5.12 of the UN Financial Regulations and Rules.

Reiterates the importance of thorough, responsive and advance planning for any mission transition process based on operational drawdown and transition plans that draw on lessons learned and take account of specific circumstances (para. 25).

The Secretariat continues to refine its approach to all aspects of mission transition and closure, taking account of specific circumstances. The Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs, the Department of Operational Support, the Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance, special political missions and United Nations country teams worked closely with host Governments and partners to ensure that United Nations activities in the country are planned in a more integrated and forward-looking manner, including for drawdown and transition plans, as further detailed in paragraphs 37 to 48 of the present report. 
The Department of Operational Support has recently completed a lessons learned process following the closure of MINUSMA and will shortly commence the process of rewriting the Liquidation Manual based on lessons learned from all mission closures since 2019.

children.text: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

table_content.text: Brief description of the recommendation or request
Action taken to implement the recommendation or request
Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (A/79/7/Add.1), as endorsed by the General Assembly in its resolution 79/258 A
Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (A/79/7/Add.1), as endorsed by the General Assembly in its resolution 79/258 A

The Advisory Committee is of the view that, as part of the programme budget, the financial performance reporting of the special political missions should be enhanced in future financial performance reports of the programme budget, including more comprehensive and detailed information on the budget implementation against provisions by mission and by budget class, with information on unliquidated obligations and the cancellation of prior-period obligations, other staff costs, among others, in particular for those missions operational in the field under thematic cluster III. (para. 10)
Information on the efforts of the Secretariat to improve the presentation of   the financial performance is provided is paragraphs 142-147.

The Advisory Committee is of the view that, for bigger and more complex special pollical missions, such as UNITAD, there is a need to report liquidation activities, in a separate report or separate section, to improve transparency, regardless of whether a budget report is required. The Committee trusts that the Secretariat will report on the liquidation activities of UNITAD in a comprehensive and detailed manner in 2025. (para. 13)

In response to the recommendation of the Advisory Committee, the reports of the Secretary-General for thematic cluster II and III (A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.3 and Add.4) contain information on the liquidation activities of UNITAD and UNITAMS.

The Advisory Committee acknowledges the efforts made to identify efficiency gains in the budgetary preparation process for the special political missions for 2025. The Committee trusts that the Secretariat will make additional efforts in all future budget submissions for both the programme budget and peacekeeping operations (para. 20)

In response to the recommendation of the Advisory Committee, which was endorsed by the General Assembly in its resolution 79/258 A, the budget proposals for the special political mission reflects efficiencies of $12.7 million, as further detailed under the section on building and strengthening a culture of efficiency

The Advisory Committee trusts that more detailed information on the new framework memorandum of understanding signed with UNOPS will … be included in the next overview report of the peacekeeping operations. (para. 31)

As indicated in the most recent report of the Secretary-General on the overview of the financing of the United Nations peacekeeping operations (A/79/788, para. 114), where programmes are implemented in partnership with UNOPS, such functions will be performed in line with the memorandum of understanding between the United Nations Secretariat and UNOPS, revised in May 2024.

The Committee recalls that, further to its resolutions 61/276 and 66/264, the General Assembly, in its resolution 74/263, requested the Secretary-General to continue his efforts to promote the nationalization of positions, whenever appropriate, as well as to build local capacity within the special political missions and to report thereon in the context of future budget submissions. (para. 36)

Special political missions continue to make efforts to ensure that the Advisory Committee’s recommendations regarding the nationalization of posts are addressed, as illustrated above, and in paragraphs 73-76.

The Advisory Committee reiterates that all vacant posts should be filled as soon as possible and trusts that updated information on the recruitment status of all vacant posts will be provided … in the next budget submission. (para. 40)
Information on the status of recruitment of long-vacant posts is presented in the supplementary information for each thematic cluster.

The Advisory Committee, while noting the improvement made in the overall compliance rates during 2023 by 27 missions, with 17 missions reaching compliance rates of 50 per cent or higher, recalls that the General Assembly, in its resolution 77/263 B, reiterated its serious concern at the low compliance with the advance purchase policy directive in all travel categories and requested the Secretary-General to take more effective measures to improve the situation in order to reduce air travel costs, given that most official travel is not carried out for the purpose of emergency situations or unforeseen requirements (resolution 77/263 B, para. 8). (para. 44)

Missions continue their efforts to comply with the Advance Purchase Policy, and monitor closely monitor to ensure full adherence to policy requirements. 
BINUH adheres to the advance purchase policy for travel to benefit from competitive ticket costs and ensures only economy class tickets are issued for all travels to attend approved trainings. CTED has been proactively coordinating with relevant member states and organizations to ensure that planning is done well in advance, thereby ensuring compliance with the policy directive. The Office of the Special Adviser on Cyprus issued a circular to all staff reminding them of the need to comply with the Advance Purchase Policy on official travel.   In the Great Lakes, the volatile and unpredictable political context in the region often necessitates last-minute travel. Despite these challenges, the Office of the Special Envoy for the Great Lakes Region remains committed to identifying and pursuing opportunities to improve compliance wherever feasible.
On 3 March 2024 UNAMA, through the bi-monthly CMS’s Bulletin, informed all staff to input their Trips (Umoja) 21 days in advance of the travel date and introduced preparation of quarterly travel plans which facilitates advance follow up by travel focal points with staff members to ensure timely Umoja action for budgeted travels.   
UNTMIS monitors and reports progress on compliance quarterly, through a comprehensive review, enabling the mission to undertake targeted actions to streamline operations and mitigate factors contributing to non-compliance. Improved coordination and communication between departments have been prioritized, particularly for routine business-as-usual meetings, to synchronize travel plans effectively.
The Verification Mission in Colombia has made a conscious effort to reduce exceptions to the 21-day policy, having implemented a portal dedicated to submitting such requests and subdelegating internally to properly monitor requests.
The DPPA-supported Cluster II SPMs have improved their compliance with the 16-day advance booking policy due to better planning of travel missions and better communication with experts, Committees and Member States on the importance of compliance with the policy. In 2023 and 2024, the average compliance rate was 71 per cent.

The Advisory Committee acknowledges the efforts made by the Secretariat to achieve cost efficiency, including by strengthening a data-driven approach in formulating budgetary requirements for 2025 for special political missions. The Committee trusts that efforts will be continued to ensure that the air fleets in the missions are used in the most effective and efficient manner and that consideration is given to any possibility of inter-mission cooperation, including with peacekeeping missions. (para. 48)

The Secretariat has taken measures to seek efficiencies and enhance the utilization of the air fleets, as further detailed in paragraphs 100 and 120. 
Missions continue to make efforts to ensure that their air operations requirements are fulfilled in the most effective and efficient manner, including through inter-mission cooperation with other special political missions or peacekeeping missions, when possible. 
In March 2024, BINUH benefited from an airlift capacity by utilizing the on call contract maintained by DOS during the first evacuation and support from United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia during the second evacuation in November 2024.
UNAMA has established an MOU with UNHAS on cooperation in air operations. The efforts include maximizing seat utilization on every flight leg through the frequent use of UNHAS flights to transport the Mission passengers when their numbers do not justify the activation of the Mission aircraft. It leads to the reduction of flight hours and fuel consumption used by the Mission. Because of its geographic location, the Mission has limited opportunities for inter-mission cooperation, including with peacekeeping missions. Such support would entail long and empty positioning and de-positioning flights.
UNSMIL implemented a quarterly data-driven review of flight schedules, smart planning, and dynamic re-tasking; and ensures coordination with the Strategic Air Operations Center in UNLB to explore potential inter-mission cooperation.
UNTMIS shares with UNSOS three fixed-wing and two rotary-wing aircraft at a ratio of 30:70. In light of the expected mandate termination of UNTMIS, UNSOS will review the overall air fleet to determine the correct fleet numbers to maintain the mandated support to UNTMIS.

The Advisory Committee acknowledges the importance of quick-impact projects and trusts that continued efforts will be made to implement more impactful projects, where relevant, and updated information included in the next budget. (para. 51)

In 2026, UNSMIL will work through quick-impact projects to enhance confidence in the Mission’s mandate in supporting the political process, reconciliation and prevention of intra- and inter-community violence.

The Advisory Committee notes the impending review of the services provided to the existing clients of the Kuwait Joint Support Office for UNAMA and UNAMI pending the drawdown of UNAMI pursuant to Security Council resolution 2732 (2024). (para. 56)
late 2024, the Department of Operational Support conducted a review of the Kuwait Joint Support Office, as detailed in paragraphs 67-70.

The Advisory Committee reiterates that the Kuwait Joint Support Office is not a shared service centre approved by the General Assembly. Furthermore, in accordance with Assembly resolution 70/248 A, any changes to the existing and future service delivery model must be approved by the Assembly. (para. 57)

Subject to the endorsement of Member States, it is the intention of the Secretariat to transfer the 16 client missions of the Kuwait Joint Support Office to the RSCE. This transition will be completed by the end of the UNAMI liquidation process which is projected to be at the end of September 2026.
The Advisory Committee notes the continued lack of clear criteria in the designation of service providers to peacekeeping and special political missions by the Secretariat. (para. 58)

As detailed in the sections on the Regional Service Centre and Kuwait Joint Support Office, the Secretariat expressed its intention to propose transfer of the 16 client missions currently supported by the KJSO to the RSCE. Upon review by the ACABQ and approval by Member States, this measure will bring the designation of service providers for peacekeeping and special political missions more closely in line with the global mandate of DOS and RSCE.

The Advisory Committee trusts that an update on a comprehensive analysis of the root causes for the substantial variances between actual vehicle and computing devices holdings and standard allocations, as well as potential update to the Standard Cost and Ratio Manual, will be provided in the next budget submission for special political missions. (para. 66)

In reviewing the vehicle holding ratios, The Secretariat found that a singular ratio for each category that was applicable to all entities was not practicable. Following consultation with client entities, it transpired that actual requirements and standard should factor the entities operations requirements as well as the functions performed by different types of personnel in support of it. As an example, functions that require night shifts or ability to respond to unforeseen circumstances allowing for a 24/7 response should be weighted in. As such, the Secretariat will need to conduct a full assessment of clients entities needs to ensure that the ratios are geared to enable the implementation of client entities' mandates.
The Office of Information and Communications Technology issues budget guidelines to provide detailed instructions on the planning, justification, and distribution of ICT resources, including updated equipment allocation ratios, lifecycle guidance, and distribution of shared and personal computing devices. It is important to note that individual missions may deviate from the guidelines based on operational requirements.

The Advisory Committee notes the continued efforts to improve the formulation and presentation of the budget submissions for special political missions for 2025, including the identification of efficiency gains (see para. 20 above), enhanced performance reporting for air operations, mine action and construction projects for field-based special political missions, under thematic cluster III, UNAMA and UNAMI. The Committee trusts that further efforts will be made in future budget submissions, such as the inclusion of the total amounts in annexes XI, XII, XIII, and XIV to the report of the Secretary-General. (para. 68)

In response to the recommendations made by the Advisory Committee, the presentation of reports of the Secretary-General and supplementary information packages have been improved to include additional information on performance reporting for air operations, mine action and construction projects for field-based special political missions, under thematic cluster III, UNAMA and UNAMI.

The Committee trusts that information on annual appointments to geographical posts by mission, level, nationality and representation status will be provided in future budget submissions for the special political missions, starting with the information from 1 January to 31 December 2024 in the proposed budget for 2026. (para. 72)

Attaining equitable geographical distribution is a high priority of the Secretary-General, and concerted efforts have been made over the years to accelerate progress. 
Information about progress in achieving equitable geographical distribution and related actions is provided in the reports of the Secretary-General on human resources management, including the report on the composition of the Secretariat: staff demographics and the report on the overview of human resources management reform for the period 2023–2024 to be submitted to the General Assembly at the first part of its resumed seventy-ninth session.

The Advisory Committee recalls that the General Assembly, in its resolution 75/253 A (sect. XVIII), requested the Secretary-General to make stronger efforts to improve geographical representation and gender balance in special political missions. Furthermore, the Assembly, in its resolution 76/246 A (sect. X), also requested the Secretary-General to take measures, including through the recruitment of new staff and by strengthening the accountability framework of the managers, to improve geographical representation and gender balance in all the special political missions and provide an update in future budget submissions, including on geographical representation by nationality. (para. 76)

The missions have taken measures to strengthen efforts to achieve equitable geographical representation in their workforce. Missions’ hiring managers are required to demonstrate, using the current data on geographical representation, the impact of such recommendations. The revised template of the selection memorandums now allows hiring managers to review, before a candidate is selected, whether the proposed selection improves the geographical representation of the mission. The data are also monitored quarterly through the management dashboard to guide the course of recruitment actions. 
The geographical representation, by country, of the international staff posts in all special political missions is provided in the supplementary information.    
BINUH reaches out to rostered candidates from unrepresented and underrepresented countries and encourages them to apply, especially female candidates, widened outreach by publishing vacancy announcements in the local media as well as online platforms such as LinkedIn and Relief Web. 
The Mission has implemented measures to increase the pool of female candidates applying for positions by waiving the French language requirement for those jobs where a working knowledge rather than fluency may be sufficient. Further, BINUH has.
In the Office of the Special Envoy for the Great Lakes Region, the geographical representation is also monitored on a quarterly basis through the management dashboard to guide the course of recruitment actions.
In July 2024, UNSMIL issued an interoffice memorandum on implementation of special measures for recruitment which entails that effective immediately, all ongoing and future recruitment processes must ensure that female candidates are given priority. This measure includes integrating gender perspectives into all aspects of our work, from development of workplans and goals, to their implementation and evaluation.
